Still everyone else involved in this film is superb especially Peter Lorre as Dr. Einstein and Raymond Massey as the Boris Karloff-like Jonathan Brewster. Great menace from Massey and wonderful spinelessness from Lorre--just terrific support to keep the film fun and entertaining when it was starting to get a little stilted.Josephine Hull, Jean Adair, John Alexander are all truly outstanding in their roles and play them with gusto (they seem to be enjoying themselves playing the roles). Also the very lovely Priscilla Lane is really quite good here too and her performance is too often overlooked and unappreciated.There's too much good here to overlook this film even though the bad is generally annoying.

If you think that punch lines miraculously become funnier if you scream them at the top of your lungs, need to be batted over the head with teeth-shatteringsound effects or believe in your heart that "The Producers" is the finest film ever created, than this farce is made for you. On the other hand, if you don't need a dictionary to understand the meaning of "obvious" or "subtlety," then this film will come off as nothing more than a brass, overrated novelty, best viewed once and only as a High School stage production. The best part of this film is the spine- tingling face of Raymond Massey.

I saw this film in 2006 with the Imaginative Cinema Society in Baltimore, MD. I hadn't seen it in some time. I was the murderous Jonathan Brewster in the play in high school. so I was very familiar with the material. I could even sit there and recite some of Raymond Massey's lines with him (just don't ask me to find my car keys from 10 minutes ago!).What a pleasure! I could scarcely believe that this chestnut, released more than 6 decades before, held up so well.Cary Grant, so suave and in control in other films, discovers he is under siege by a legion of corpses. This legion is composed of gentlemen who have been drafted to the cause. They have reached their terminus a tad prematurely thanks to the "kindness" of his lovely old aunts.Grants leaping Mortimer, Massey's looming Jonathan and John Alexander bringing his stage role of Teddy to the screen; all under the hand of Frank Capra at the height of his powers, make this a wonderfully fresh and watchable comedy after all these years.Let's see if anyone's writing about a current teen-slacker comedy in such glowing terms 6 decades hence.

I didn't know that 1940s movies could be gimmicky, but this one is. I have watched quite a few screwball comedies from this era, and most of them show a director's steady hand, giving the story a nice build-up and flow; not to mention civil, timeless acting performances and loving cinematography. This film is a very different type of animal: Every frame, every line is contrived to an absurd degree. The scriptwriter and the director seem to have insisted that every second of the movie MUST be rip-roaringly, thigh-slappingly funny, or else! Needless to say, it doesn't work. The human brain is not built to absorb this kind of an all-out onslaught. The non-stop, frenetic action and the relentless fishing for laughs kill the story within the first few minutes. Cary Grant - who looks more stereotypically Semitic rather than a matinée idol - gives his level best in reacting and in physical comedy. But it's not enough to salvage this mess.

reviews.review_title: Frank Capra and the screenwriters made this movie painful.
reviews.content: I have attempted to enjoy this movie, which I own, for many decades. I haven't tossed it, because I figure it must be a problem with me that I can't enjoy it. Unlike, for example, Capra's 'You Can't Take It With You,' there is no character anchoring the "madcap." There is no balance, whatsoever, although Peter Lorre's character, Dr. Einstein, comes closest, and he seems to get the joke.Ultimately, I think this was Peter Lorre's movie. Had I first seen Grant in this movie, I doubt I would have sought out another in which he starred. (On the other hand, Raymond Massey's 'Jonathan Brewster' seems almost a type-casting that is maintained through his other work, and I have, in fact, avoided watching him).Viewers are immediately introduced to the radiant Priscilla Lane, whose fine acting is almost brutally cut by Capra. She so connects with the camera and the audience, that it is a wonder she was cast, as her treatment in this film is so offensive.All other supporting cast elegantly portray their characters, and I wonder how it is that Capra let them. 'Mortimer' - Grant is only somewhat less empathetic than the charging, bugle-blasting.'Teddy Roosevelt Brewster'.I know. Given my take on it, it's stupid to keep attempting to watch this movie for other than the set decorations.

This is one of my favorites! Cary Grant is so funny in this film. I found myself laughing from beginning to end. One of my favorite parts is when he chases the old man out of the house and trips over the chair. I lost it, it was great. Anyone who wouldnt enjoy this, well there has to be something wrong with them. This is one of the funniest movies ever made!

reviews.review_title: Unfairly loved: a sick, senseless, stupid farce.
reviews.content: Another unimaginably bad movie whose classic status mystifies me. Cary Grant is at his rubber-faced worst. Even Peter Lorre is but a shadow of his fine evil self. The jokes are stupid and pretentious at times: a metatheatrical, postmodern, self-referential, and utterly self-indulgent sense of humor produces cracks such as Grant saying "in this play I saw on Broadway, there's a character who gets tied up without even knowing what's going on! ISN'T THAT FUNNY?" while he himself is being tied up by the bad guys. A sick, weird sentimentalism occurs around Grant's aunts and their hideous crimes, which are regarded mysteriously as funny. This is supposed to be a comedy, but a nasty and not at all funny cruelty animates many of the supposedly funny moments. Grant's treatment of his fiancee is a study in ugliness. The movie treats his evil aunts as harmless if eccentric ladies; the entire idea of a character who has been surgically altered to resemble Boris Karloff is inherently stupid. I won't be able to watch a Cary Grant film for a long while.

reviews.review_title: I Was Shocked...SHOCKED at how awful this film was.
reviews.content: This is one of those "classics" that I never got around seeing, until tonight, and I wish I hadn't.The premise of sweet old ladies killing men and burying them in the cellar is a good one, but oh, God, the script and performances are more like cartoons than a dark comedy as it was advertised to be.Cary Grant is the worst thing here. One of our greatest stars, mugging it up and acting like Fred McMurry on speed is an insult to those who come here with expectations of good works. It doesn't work. How could it.The film is filled with excellent actors from Grant to Josephine Hull as Aunt Abby Brewster, Jean Adair as Aunt Martha Brewster, Raymond Massey as Jonathan Brewster, Peter Lorre as Dr. Herman Einstein not to mention Jack Carson, James Gleason and Edward Everett Horton for flavor.But the whole flavor of the film is that of the tragedy of what could have been. 1940's Brooklyn, murder, old ladies, great actors...all lost is a simply pathetic attempt at........My God...I just don't know. I don't know what the Hell they were trying to do. It doesn't seem to be a failure. Frank Capra seems quite confident is his pursuit.Of just what; is lost to history.

I love this movie for its even amounts of comedy, dark humor and stark terror. I've never cared much for Cary Grant, but in this movie he really shows off wonderful split second timing and talent for comedy as he accidentally stumbles on his darling old aunts' secrets. Raymond Massey and Peter Lorre steal all of their scenes as the fast paced plot keeps you riveted and thrilled and laughing out loud as Grant proves how hard it is to keep a secret, and a dead man down. Monkeyshines are all around in this remarkably timeless movie ! Ten stars !!

reviews.review_title: Hilarious black comedy from Frank "Mr. America" Capra
reviews.content: Black comedies from the 1940's are always an interesting watch. What makes them more interesting is if they're made by Frank Capra, Mr. Wholesome America himself! I believe this is sort of his "skeleton in the closet" picture, an abrupt change from his usual cleancut, all-American picture. This was another one of AFI's Top 100 Funniest Movies of All Time (#30), but I think HAROLD AND MAUDE (#45) is funnier.Based on an original play, Cary Grant is Mortimer Brewster, a drama critic who loves his two old aunts Abby (Josephine Hull) and Martha (Jean Adair) and his brother Teddy, who thinks he's President Teddy Roosevelt! Mortimer discovers that his two sweet old aunts invite elderly courters inside and poison them with wine laced with arsenic, then hide the bodies in the cellar so "Roosevelt" can bury them in "the Panama Canal". To add to his surprise, his psychotic murderous brother Johnny (Raymond Massey) and his sidekick Dr. Einstein (Peter Lorre) have escaped from jail and have taken up residence in the house. How will he ever explain this to his new wife? And does this mean insanity runs in the family?Cary Grant has impeccable comic timing, proven here by his reactions to the shocking truth about his aunts and his handling of the facts. I've never been much of a fan of Grant's, what with his annoying voice, but here he gives a wonderful comic performance. He was always a better comic actor than a dramatic actor, anyway. You have to love the scene where he catches the sisters trying to poison a prospective boarder in the house. Josephine Hull and Jean Adair are superb as the two little old ladies who look as if they wouldn't hurt a fly. Their best scenes are when they are explaining their crimes to Mortimer, so matter-of-fact, as if they're describing a family recipe for apple pie. Raymond Massey takes over the role of Johnny from stage actor Boris Karloff (Johnny is constantly told, "You look like Karloff!") and is very creepy. Peter Lorre, a personal favorite, is great as the heavy drinker Dr. Einstein. Edward Everett Horton is the head of an insane asylum; he is best-known as the narrator of "Fractured Fairy Tales" on "The Rocky and Bullwinkle Show" and is fantastic in POCKETFUL OF MIRACLES. Frank Capra is a genius and every film of his is an instant classic. This will surprise those who have only seen Capra's IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE, but is a pleasant surprise indeed.

Honestly, aside from the story itself, the greatest element of this movie is Cary Grant. He is delightfully whimsical, and rather sweet as the nephew of a couple of serial murderers who feel the need to alleviate the suffering of lonely older gentlemen via good company, a home cooked meal, and poisoned wine in the parlor.Nothing including his own marriage to the girl next door could stop his caring for the old gals in a time of great need. Even the return of his psychopathic brother did not alter his caring for the old girls.While the delivery is tongue in cheek, the story is quite intense at times, generating some palatable suspense, even while it makes fun of itself. Oddly enough, that fact does not break or lessen the suspenseful feel, where appropriate.The relationship the Aunts enjoy both with one another and with everyone else in their sphere, is quite lovely in a Fiendish sort of way. They reserve the "special" wine for "special" company, excluding the police officers, neighbors, and mail carriers who stop by to pay their respects. No one knows. No one suspects.I like Cary Grant, and unlike a myriad of other reviewers, I like him well in this. He plays the comedic aspects off with a frantic dignity and grace. This is one of my all time favorites.It rates a 9.2/10 from......the Fiend :.

Cary Grant a recently married confirmed bachelor is spending his honeymoon with his crazy family as he discovers his aunts are at the forefront of euthanasia. His brother Jonathan (Raymond Massey) comes to visit, dragging along Peter Lorre and a corpse. John Alexander believes he is Teddy Roosevelt and buries yellow fever victims in the basement "canal."This was a delightful comedy. I was confused by the opening claiming to be Halloween and a baseball game was being played. There was no mention of Halloween in the feature.

I have always enjoyed Cary Grant's acting. I think he was a method actor in a time when method acting wasn't even called that. It was around longer than him, but it doesn't change things.Cary Grant has a way of looking at a camera, breaking the third wall, and asking 'Why me?' with his eyes that is just perfect and hilarious.It is also what makes him the best performer for this skit.Let's be clear, it is basically a comedic skit from the days of theater. It is dark, funny, and ruins poor Mortimer's day. I have seen this with a lot of people, and I am usually introducing them to Cary Grant. I can't think of anyone who hasn't burst into laughter when they watch this.I am rating this as a 10/10, but it is definitely as a bump. I would give it a genuine review of 8/10. No plot or character development. It is barely a 'movie' in the modern sense of the word. It is however, the best performance of the skit you will ever see, and it is darkly hilarious.

Arsenic and Old Lace (1944) is an interesting studio-era comedy with numerous one-liner jokes and physical comedy. But throughout the film it is painfully obvious that it was a film made to sell. With fast shots and a quick script, the film moves well but suffers in other areas. Cary Grant (Mortimer Brewster) plays a well designed role and his acting is quite good, but his counterpart Pricsilla Lane (Elaine Harper) doesen't seem like a good enough fit. The two characters do not compliment each other well and there is no visible comedic conflict between them, a very important part of any comedic film. The story line itself is good and fairly well thought out, but its execution on screen is sub par. Among the early films I've seen this one ranks fairly low, it is a simple Hollywood production with not much more than a witty script and decent acting.

Let me start by saying that Cary Grant is probably my favourite actor. He seemed, at his best, to be able find comedy in almost any situation, but always seemed to retain a level so noticeably absent in the "gross-out" comedies of today.I've seen most of him films at least twice and masterpieces like "His Girl Friday" several times.But "Arsenic and old Lace" simply leaves me cold. Grant's over-reacting reduces his performance to the level one could expect from any ordinary comic actor.It's left to Raymond Massey to add some desperately needed "quiet" time in a film that seems to be frantic beyond anything that makes sense.Perhaps the IMDb Trivia section for the movie sums it up: "Hated his performance in Arsenic and Old Lace (1944), saying it was way too over the top and that it was his least favorite film"

This is Cary Grant at his best! Nobody makes movies like this anymore. A delightful comedy of errors about 2 maiden aunts & their nephew[played by Cary Grant].  The aunts make these delicious cookies and give them to visitors with very comedic & unexpected results. I have seen this many times & it is always enjoyable & full of laughs. Once you see you will know why it is a CLASSIC...

Arsenic and Old Lace is one of the funniest films ever made. Cary Grant is at his confused best as he tries to figure outwhat to do about his kindly old aunts bumping off old men.  Agreat script with great direction on Frank Capra's part keepsthe pace moving quickly.  Some of the best moments come fromGrant's double takes and Teddy charging up the stairs.  One ofthe best written scenes is how Grant convinces Teddy thatBrewster is really a codename for Roosevelt.  A top notch comedythat will probably never be out done.  Try not laughing at thisone, you won't be able to keep a straight face

Newly weds return to family home, to find really strange things going on.I bet they plugged Grant into a nuclear reactor since he mugs it up faster than a Ferrari changes RPM's. The movie amounts to a wild exercise in black madcap humor. No wonder Warners made a ton of money at the box office. Director Capra keeps things moving in overdrive, and he better, because he's only got two sets to work with. Great cast. I love Raymond Massey's Frankenstein, and a face put together with a sewing machine. And what about John Alexander. He's got the role of a lifetime, even if it qualifies him for the all-time loony bin. Can't help but wonder if he ever looked at a staircase normally again. And what about those sweet old ladies, Adair and Hull. They're ideal for anybody's aunts, that is, as long as you stay away from their elderberry wine. Watch out too for those padded window seats. I just feel sorry for Priscilla Lane. Here she is the only normal one amid all the certified lunacy. Can't help but notice how things pivot on the notion that some murders are less onerous than others. After all, the black humor wouldn't be funny if the victims were younger or more connected.Anyhow, the movie made a big impression on me as a kid, probably all the unbridled craziness. And I've never been able to look at Teddy Roosevelt in a presidential way since. Yet, I'm happy to say, I still get as many laughs now as I did then. And so will you, even if it is a second or third time around. That is, if you like madcap to the max.

I found this film to be entertaining at first, but after awhile it begins to wear on you. The premise is excellent and Cary Grant has his moments, but the two aunts (Josephine Hull and Jean Adair) and his newly wed (Priscilla Lane) are the real stars of the film. It's a shame their characters weren't in the film more.The film was way too long and the plot became overly complicated with too many characters. It felt like the film fell apart midway through and then floundered its way to the end. For the first 10 to 20 minutes you will love Cary Grant, by the end you'll want him to drink the wine. I would not recommend this film for anyone without a high pain threshold.

The 132th best movie of all time? What have I missed? Okay it's been made by the supertastic Frank Capra but I really can't escape the feeling that this is a very mediocre movie. The story is simple (and funny) but Brewster, a theatrecritic, decides to marry but he first has to overwin the strange habits of his family (two aunts who already have killed 13 men and who have buried the bodies in the cellar, someone who thinks he is President Roosevelt). And here is where the problem starts as Arsenic and old lace is both a vaudeville mixed with horror (it was the aim of Capra to let Boris Karloff playing in here but in the end all he got was a doppelganger) that will remind you of what some decades later would become The Addams Family. The biggest problem is a totally misplaced Cary Grant who really is overacting (Grant himself never liked his work in here). "Arsenic and old lace" is nice slapstick for some rainy Saturdayafternoons but certainly nothing more.

This is the best Halloween Movie ever.  It has no ghosts.  It has no vampires.  It has no Evil Overlord.  What it does have is one of the best scripts and best editing of any film I've ever seen.  Cary Grant and Co. turn a small, quiet household into a den of horrors in the most hilarious fashion that you never see it coming.  And no blood is spilled, no semi naked women have their clothing torn, no monsters lurk below, above or anywhere outside, and no director makes a cameo!  Yes, this may turn some people off immediately but not seeing these things is what this film is all about.  There's even a Boris Karloff reference or two to spoof the grandmaster's ubiquitous appearances in films of the genre.  (I understand he was in the stage play.)  It's what you don't see that gets you.  It's stated over and over again so you understand exactly what is going on in the chaos but you never see it.  Horror fans know that it's the fear the unknown generates that gets you.  Knowing and seeing it is one thing, knowing but never seeing it is far more tantalizing and far more difficult to pull off. Here, it's done with ease.  10 out of 10.
Cary grant is priceless! But his to Aunts are a riot so simple and believable I loved it every time I see it I love it more

Frank Capra's screwball comedy to end all screwball comedies starring a master of the genre, Cary Grant. Mortimer Brewster (Grant) has just gotten married to Elaine Harper (Priscilla Lane) and takes her home to tell his two sweet old aunts (Josephine Hull, Jean Adair) the news. While there, he discovers that the two old ladies are murderers! They've been poisoning lonely old men for years and having their crazy brother Teddy (who believes himself Teddy Roosevelt) bury them in the cellar. As if that's not enough, Mortimer's long-lost criminally insane brother Jonathan (Raymond Massey) shows up with his plastic surgeon Dr. Einstein (Peter Lorre).Frank Capra often included bits of comedy in his dramatic films but this is one of the few cases where he tackled the genre head-on. It's a brilliant blend of screwball and black comedy with an exceptional cast that knocks it out of the park. The film maintains an insanely manic pace like no other comedy I can think of. Cary Grant brilliantly holds the whole thing together. Few other actors could match his comedic talent while also being good at dramatic leading man roles. Perhaps Jimmy Stewart but I can't think of another. Raymond Massey, partially hidden behind makeup to give him a Frankenstein's monsterish appearance, is wonderful. Massey was a versatile actor who seldom gets the respect he deserves. The in-joke with his character resembling Boris Karloff (who played the role on stage) is great fun, especially for a huge Karloff fan like myself. Peter Lorre shines in every scene he's in, which should surprise no one familiar with this terrific actor. Hull and Adair were tailor-made for the roles of the aunts. John Alexander as Teddy and Priscilla Lane are also enjoyable. Let's not forget some great character actors in memorable roles: Edward Everett Horton, Jack Carson, James Gleason, Grant Mitchell, and John Ridgely. A truly classic comedy. One of the all-time greats.

I don't know how this was received at the time (1944) but I think it's safe to think in terms of a spectrum spanning nothing lower than fair and nothing higher than sensational. Capra sandwiched this in between Meet John Doe and It's A Wonderful Life and punctuated them by eleven of his acclaimed 'Why We Fight' documentaries, seven between Doe and Lace, four between Lace and Life. With neither Doe nor Life aspiring to a barrel of laffs it's reasonable to assume that Capra satisfied a craving for comedy here. For me, seeing it for the first time in 2010 it was vastly entertaining and I confess to the odd moment of laughing out loud. Okay, Cary Grant, never one to let a chance to mug remain unmolested and a living and breathing definition of OTT indulges himself in both here. In spades. Still, we find ourselves accepting it; like an earlier Capra comedy, You Can't Take It With You, which it resembles inasmuch as both feature eccentric families, it was based on a stage play - in fact Lace was still running on Broadway at the time of shooting - and the movie retained three principals, Josephine Hull, Jean Adair and John Alexander, all outstanding. There's a nice touch when the script tries to wrong-foot us in the first reel, when, having established Mortimer Brewster (Grant) as not merely a misogynist, but one who has gone so far as to write at least one book denouncing marriage, we see him tie the knot with Priscilla Lane, not exactly a chore, and we settle down for a battle of the sexes only to discover that the real story is about his two maiden aunts - again presented as pussycats - who have, albeit in the best possible taste, seen off between twelve and thirteen elderly and lonely gentlemen via their lethal elderberry wine, only one to a customer. These are disposed of in the cellar by a brother who thinks he is 1) Teddy Roosevelt and 2) digging the Panama Canal. Throw in a second brother, mass murderer Raymond Massy, who turns up out of the blue bearing more than a passing resemblance to Boris Karloff in Frankenstein monster mode, accompanied by 'Doctor' Einstein, Peter Lorre, ready and willing to perform more plastic surgery, together with a stiff of their own and the words cup runneth over spring to mind. As they say round the poolroom they don#t make them like this anymore.

When this film was originally released, critics at the time wrote that Cary Grant over-acted.  Time has proven them wrong.  It's a brilliant performance.  Because the story itself is so "over the top," Cary can (and does) chew up the scenery.  Josephine Hull, who later went on to win an Oscar for "Harvey," plays one of the aunts.  She, like the rest of the cast, is hilarious.

Frank Capra directed this screen adaptation of the hit Broadway farce Arsenic Old Lace just a few months after it premiered, however Warners was contractually committed to not releasing the film till it ended its New York run. As the play was one of the longest running ever in the history of Broadway, it wasn't released for three more years! This goes to show what a big hit this black comedy was. Even today, when watching the screen version it's easy to see why. The story is fast-faced, the characters nearly all either mad or eccentric, and the central idea is highly original: a pair of kindly old spinsters are discovered, by their newly married theater critic nephew, to be poisoning male guests in their Brooklyn home, not out of malice but due to their kindness. They want to put the old gentlemen out of their misery, so they offer them elderberry wine laced with arsenic. The events unfold on Halloween eve is an added bonus, as it adds a nice touch of holiday cheer and fear.I've seen this movie on television, alone and with others, and in a crowded theater, and it never fails to please. There's something so wacky and good natured about it that it draws me in, as much for its charm as its wit: the movie enchants, puts one at ease and never, despite its theme of serial killing, offends. It's rather like the old ladies at the center of the story, quaint and disarming. Even with the body in the window seat,--and eleven more in the basement!--and criminal nephew Jonathan lurking about, it feels upbeat, almost reassuring in its mood, like a slice of Americana. That so much of the dialog echoes the America of seventy years ago,--references to the Roosevelts, the long gone from Brooklyn Dodgers, rumble seats, the fact that Jonathan's botched plastic surgery makes him look like horror star Boris Karloff (who played the part in the Broadway production but not in the movie)--make it feel like a product of its time in the best sense of the term: it's from a bygone era, when cops walked the beat, people put room to rent signs in their front windows, sang hymns in the parlor, that's long vanished. Arsenic and Old Lace may be about murders and dead bodies lying around the house, yet it feels warm and cozy.The production is modest in scale, as befits a film adaptation of a play, and Capra wisely chose to not "open it up" too much. Most of the action takes place in the family's home, and the central set is beautifully designed, worthy of an Academy Award. It's a handsome movie, and it's a credit to its director and cast that despited its limited setting it feels larger than life. As the sane brother, Mortimer, Cary Grant hams up a storm. I like his manic playing, many don't. I think that the decision to present Mortimer as crazier seeming than his batty family was the correct decision. Josephine Hull and Jean Adair recreate their Broadway roles as aunts Abby and Martha, and don't miss a beat. Nor does Raymond Massey as Jonathan. I think that Massey works perfectly in the film. Many wish that Karloff could have played the part. Massey strikes me as a better fit, as while he's made up to look monstrous, his voice and manner are American, thus he only looks like Boris Karloff. He doesn't sound like him. Also, he practically whispers all his lines, which makes his character come off as genuinely menacing. Peter Lorre shines as his assistant, Dr. Einstein (Heidelberg, 1919). The writing (much of the play was rumored to have been rewritten by its producers, Howard Lindsay and Russell Crouse) more than gets the job done without drawing attention to itself; and some of the best lines,--"murder doesn't run in my family, it practically gallops", "not the Melbourne method!"--are fondly remembered even today and are still quoted by fans of the play.

reviews.review_title: Is That a Body in Your Window Seat or Are You Just Happy to See Me?
reviews.content: Cary Grant works his tail off in this morbid comedy with an unusually high body count.Grant brings his brand-new wife (a perky Priscilla Lane) home to meet his two spinster aunts -- only to make the grisly discovery that his aunts have been murdering lonely male boarders and burying them in the basement. If this weren't stressful enough, Grant's sociopathic brother (played humorously by Raymond Massey) shows up with a body of his own to get rid of. What's a man to do? Frank Capra does a pretty good job of blending the screwball with the macabre, and nearly every joke and bit of physical comedy falls to Grant, who breezes through the whole movie with aplomb. It's a bit longer than it needs to be (o.k. so maybe it's a LOT longer than it needs to be), but it's still a lot of fun.Grade: A-

reviews.review_title: Over the top but it needs to be
reviews.content: Apparently, Cary Grant didn't rate his performance in Arsenic and old lace, believing it to be, hammy. The fact is, he certainly gives it everything but in the context of the film itself, his performance is essentially perfect.This film is, of course, set in the realms of utter nonsense and fantasy but that simply heightens the satisfaction one gets, once you've settled in for the ride. It starts by establishing the relationship Grant has with Lane and then quickly sets up the family as having a severe history of mental illness (not real mental illness of course, comedic mental illness).once these things are set up, we quickly go onto the silly journey of the film and watch Grant react to numerous fantastical situations. Grant's double takes are a joy to watch and everyone does there bit to keep the momentum going until we get to the resolution.The film is a stage play farce of the best kind and the light hearted nature of the film is something all players are aware of, leading to the moment when Grant actually looks into the camera. pure entertainment of the best sort. They don't make em like this anymore.This is my favourite Grant film and i'm sure Grant eventually realised his performance isn't hammy at all but rather brilliant... it's spot on (and even if he never realised it, everyone else did)

reviews.review_title: The best one-man screwball comedy role
reviews.content: "Arsenic and Old Lace" has entertained people for decades. The original Broadway production ran more than 1,400 performances from January, 1941, to June, 1944. It since has been among the favorite of stage plays for neighborhood theaters, high schools and colleges. But its widest appeal comes from this 1944 Warner Brothers film, starring Cary Grant.Considering Hollywood's penchant for remakes of older successful films, it's worth noting that this comedy classic has not been tried again for the silver screen. I suspect that the movie makers who watch this great classic realize that they probably couldn't find a cast today that would pull it off as well, let alone any better. Three TV productions were made – in 1962, 1969 and 1971. The 1962 film with Tony Randall in the lead role, was quite good, but still well behind this original. Even with some better known female leads for the two Brewster sisters, none of those TV films could equal or better this original classic. All of the cast excel in this film. But Cary Grant's Mortimer Brewster is over the top funny. His may be the best one-man screwball comedy role of all time. Grant shows his very capable acting ability in this frantic, forgetful, fast-paced, ranting, and rushing role. His double-takes, facial expressions, and almost constant state of anxiety drive the plot after a short time into the film. But for a couple of scenes outside and at the marriage bureau, all the action takes place in one large set. The living room of the Brewster home is one mad-cap funny scene after another. This is a film the whole family should enjoy. It is a must for any film library.

reviews.review_title: It's a Halloween film, but it's great to watch any time of the year when you're just in need of laughter!
reviews.content: We're living in a depressing time period. School shootings, unsafe TikTok trends, threats to voting rights and democracy, people arguing on social media. Hearing and reading about such a high volume of negativity day in and day out reaches a point of being tiresome. I think that's why I love classic movies so much. They're like my personal escapism. I had watched Arsenic and Old Lace as a kid. In terms of the scenes and dialogue, I hardly remembered anything. After discovering more of Cary Grant's movies as an adult, and subsequently becoming a fan, I was excited to watch it again. Based on a play by Joseph Kesselring, it's a story about Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant) a writer and theater critic who's vehemently anti-marriage, but goes along with marrying a woman named Elaine Harper (Priscilla Lane), a minister's daughter. She lives next door to his aunts, played by Jean Adair and Josephine Hull. They're sweet and harmless, or so it appears. Mortimer is headed to Niagara Falls for his honeymoon, but gets sidetracked when he finds out his aunts have been killing people. His brother (John Alexander) - who identifies as Teddy Roosevelt - buries them in the basement, thinking they're yellow fever victims. Mortimer's other brother, Jonathan (Raymond Massey) - he looks like Frankenstein - is a murderer on the run from the police. He hides out in the aunts' house with his alcoholic plastic surgeon, Dr. Herman Einstein (Peter Lorre). Mortimer predominantly spends his time trying to get his brother who thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt committed to a mental hospital called Happydale, while Jonathan and Dr. Einstein are attempting to conceal their victim's body in the aunts' house. People who don't like this movie are taking it too seriously. It's quite impossible not to laugh. Cary Grant's facial expressions were hilarious. I think it's interesting how a reviewer mentioned that this film is probably the least suave he had ever been, which more closely resembled how he behaved when he was just existing as a human and not acting. So I'm guessing he was dorky off screen. I feel like that made his performance all the more enjoyable, because he was pretty much being himself. Comedic actors are so irritating to watch nowadays. Modern Hollywood is just overrated celebrities who aren't funny, talented, or attractive. I see nothing wrong with Arsenic and Old Lace. It does make humor out of psychosis, which some people may find offensive, but you can't watch this through a 21st century lens. I don't normally like dark comedies, but I can watch this over and over again. It's an excellent film if you've had a long day or week.

Frank Capra directed this hilarious film based on the hit play. Cary Grant plays Mortimer Brewster, a play critic and renowned bachelor who has just gotten married to Elaine Harper(played by Priscilla Lane) and goes home to avoid the press, and see his beloved aunts, only to discover that they are mass murderers of lonely old men they poisoned with elderberry wine! Horrified, he tries to have them committed, but the return of Jonathan Brewster(Raymond Massey) with his colleague Dr. Einstein(Peter Lorre) thwarts this, as he is a more sinister mass murderer, who has plans for poor Mortimer...Set on a madcap Halloween, this wild and dark-humored comedy is uproarious, with crazy uncle Teddy(convinced he is Teddy Roosevelt) & a nosy policeman(played by Jack Carson) adding to the fun. One of the best comedies ever made, though with moments of genuine tension and wonderfully atmospheric. A treasure to be watched all year round.

reviews.review_title: Cary's Face is worth the price of admission!!!!!
reviews.content: Cary Grant is in his prime as he watches his world collapse around him. The look on his face as he realizes that there's a dead body in the trunk is priceless!!!  Let yourself be carried away with this screwball comedy... it's a SOLID TEN!!!!!!!!!!

This is supposed to be a black comedy, which requires characters who are essentially amoral. And while it has plenty of characters like that, Cary Grant's character is "straight," though, horrified to find out that his sweet old aunts have poisoned a dozen men. Rather than act like a normal person, he instead decides to become an accessory to the crimes by framing his crazy but harmless brother and getting him institutionalized and cruelly ignoring his sweet new wife. Why he is so willing to hurt himself and other innocents to protect his aunts, who are serial killers, is never explained. I do not understand why this is "comedy," whether black or otherwise.

'Arsenic & Old Lace (1944)' is the kind of comedy they simply don't make anymore, a fantastic farce featuring larger-than-life characters and everything than can go wrong going wrong in style. It's a great time, enjoyable pretty much from the first frame to the last. The performances are all on-point, especially that of leading man Grant who runs around in flustered frustration and does more double takes than you can shake a stick at. It's his near cartoony performance (at times, it's like watching a live-action 'Looney Tune') that gives most of the piece its life, effortlessly energising any scene and provoking genuine laughs at a simple facial expression. Of course, it's not realistic (Grant considered this to be a low-point in his acting career precisely because it's so over-the-top) but it isn't supposed to be. For what it is, it's phenomenal. The witty script keeps the pace up and the laughs coming. It's obviously adapted from a stage play, with almost only one location and a lot of long-winded dialogue. This isn't an issue, though, as Capra keeps things feeling cinematic enough to warrant the transition. It's the kind of film that sets all its dominoes up and then delights in teasing their toppling. It's also a surprisingly tense experience, with moments of genuine danger balancing out its otherwise silly antics. Its ending perhaps doesn't explode as much as you'd expect. Still, it does a good job of maintaining suspense and, eventually, finishes things off on a high. Plus, despite some areas that are a bit iffy (such as the depiction of one character's mental illness), it mostly withstands the test of time. It's a fun, fast-paced farce with plenty of laughs and even more smiles. 8/10

This is a Frank Capra's homicidal farce which adapted from a sensational Broadway play in the 40's. The film version was quite successful in the box office as well at that time and has preserved its classic status until today. Frank Capra is my favorite Hollywood director of the Golden Age and I keep consistently watching his opuses all these years and will continue in the future too. Arsenic And Old Lace is among his finest works without doubt, nevertheless the theatrical attribute on the contrary hampers the film from fetching its altitude which it should had reached. To to specific, what I mean is the tempo for the audience to assimilate the entire plot is in haste despite of its 118- minutes running time, all the characters seem to convey their performances in a rapid speed without rendering much time for us to ruminate, lest we would sense its logically inconsequent absurdities. I was enlightened to watch the first half of the film, the two innocently murderous Brewster aunties are truly one of a kind (thanks to Josephine Hull and Jean Adair's sincerely over-the- top performances), on the other hand, the main protagonist Cary Grant is physically engaged himself into the play while the awkwardness residually shows off as if himself is aware of the unedifying plot and wish it would finish asap. Raymond Massey, who replaced Boris Karloff in the film version, put on a new look as a mimicry of Boris and being the sole villain in the film, his presence and the conversations between him and Peter Lorre (the short and coward doctor from Germany) establish a fresh yet scaring B-film flavor, which pitifully diminishes under the pressure of the pervasively farcical aura. After all, I have no intention and ability to make an essay to discuss the love-hate relationship between play and film, however I am conscious that maybe I am a lesser theatrical enthusiast as I thought, which is definitely new for me.

reviews.review_title: This dark comedy from Frank Capra is excellent, Cary Grant heads a great cast
reviews.content: Though you may tire of Cary Grant's frenetic behavior and exasperated exclamations ("ow"'s and "oh dear"'s) while watching it, this is a very funny Frank Capra (produced and directed) film starring Grant as famous writer-critic Mortimer Brewster, formerly a confirmed bachelor, and his newlywed wife Priscilla Lane.It features an excellent supporting cast that includes Raymond Massey (playing the 'inside-joke' role that Boris Karloff originated on Broadway) and Peter Lorre, and Josephine Hull (known best for her Oscar winning role in Harvey (1950)) and Jean Adair. Additionally, Jack Carson, John Ridgely, Edward McNamara and James Gleason play police officers; Grant Mitchell, Edward Everett Horton and Charles Lane also appear.Just after Grant marries Lane, he discovers that his sweet ole Aunts (Hull and Adair) have been bumping off unsuspecting lonely old gentlemen with elderberry wine and burying them in their basement (!), to which he later remarks: "Insanity runs in my family ... it practically gallops."John Alexander plays another Brewster residing in the otherwise quiet (next to a cemetery) residence; convinced that he's President Teddy Roosevelt, he runs up the stairs (e.g. San Juan Hill) yelling "Charge!" every 15 minutes or so throughout the movie.Massey plays Mortimer's long lost crazed and murderous brother Jonathan; Lorre is "Johnny's" accomplice and plastic surgeon, Dr. Einstein.Scripted by Julius J. & Philip G. Epstein, from the successful (and long-running) stage play written by Joseph Kesselring, this comedy was completely ignored by the Academy (in part because it was released in theaters almost 3 years after it was filmed, per contract until the play had closed), though it's 30th on AFI's 100 Funniest Movies list.

Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant) is a happy man - he's about to marry the love of his life, Elaine (Priscilla Lane).  Everything seems to be going well until he visits his aunts, Abby (Josephine Hull) and Martha (Jean Adair). While htere, his long lost brother Jonathan (Raymond Massey) shows up with his associate, Dr. Einstein (Peter Lorre).  As it turns out, Jonathan has now become a hardened criminal, having killed a dozen people and bringing along the doctor to do plastic surgery on his face to disguise him.  The conflict is compounded by their crazy relative Teddy (John Alexander), who thinks he's Theodore Roosevelt.This is a great film, a must-see classic.  Never have I seen a movie dance the line of being both a comedy and a crime drama so easily.  This is especially impressive when you consider the fact that this was made in the 40's.  And I must mention Raymond Massey's performance here.  Man, what an actor!  He shines brighter than anyone else here, even when the whole cast is still good.

reviews.review_title: Today he is not quite himself
reviews.content: We're living in the crazy world, aren't we? And it's not easy to keep our sanity when so much madness is happening all around us every single day; we're surrounded by insane people who only pretend to be normal when in reality you really can't tell one from the other because those same people are convinced of certain quantity of their marbles and when you can't know for sure if you are alright or not that doesn't help one bit... but sure makes a lot of fun while you're at it.1944's "Arsenic and old lace" is Frank Capra's black comedy starring the great Cary Grant in probably his most comedic role ever. This movie is about the only black comedy I have ever liked which makes it so unique to my collection and to the world of cinema as well. It tells a story of Mortimer Brewster and his family tree which seems to be rotten to the core - the day he marries he finds out that everyone in his family is a mass murderer. Don't you just hate when that happens?When I first had the pleasure of watching this fantastic movie I laughed so hard I had to pause multiple times to catch my breath. The second time nothing has changed. Cary Grant and his facial expressions alone are worth all the recognition and fame "Arsenic and old lace" might have not been getting over the years because of its controversial topics but it is what it is. Frank Capra is a master and he can turn anything into a piece of gold.Every actor and actress in this picture show their best performances and the whole thing looks just like a theater play it was originally adapted from and Max Steiner's score accompanies it perfectly. Once I believed that there are certain things you can't joke about but after watching this movie I realized something else: if it's funny and it works in the frame of the movie concept then it's more than enough to be considered excellent.

There were some very funny moments and situations in this movie, but overall I find it to be a somewhat uneven and overlong (115 minutes) comedy. Though it builds a delirious, chaotic atmosphere very convincingly, with characters that get nuttier by the minute, it still isn't as good as it could've been. I find Cary Grant's overacting much more justifiable now that I've watched the picture twice (the first time, you may not be prepared for how crazy he acts), and there are many moments of inspired teamwork (great underplaying by Peter Lorre, and John Alexander is perfect) - but isn't Raymond Massey a little too gloomy and menacing for a comedy, even a "black" one? (**1/2)

***SPOILERS*** One of the screwiest screwball comedies ever made "Arsenic & Old Lace" has the usual cool and handsome as well as suave & sophisticated Cary Grant as well known theater critic and life long bachelor Mortimer Brewster lose it to the point when by the time the film is over he's about to be committed to the Happy Dale Sanitarium together with his crazy brother Teddy,John Alexander, and two sweet nutty as well as homicidal aunts Abby & Martha, Josephine Hull & Joan Adair.Mortimer who finally decided to tie the knot with pretty Brooklyn girl Elaine Harper, Priscilla Lane, at City Hall went across the East River to Brooklyn Heights to spent the evening with his two spinster aunts Abby & Martha whom he hasn't seen in almost 20 years. It doesn't take long for Mortimer to realize that both Aunt Abby & Martha have been helping out the homeless and down in the dumps old men in the neighborhood by treating them to a last meal that consisted of small doses of cyanide and arsenic in order to give them, in that they were on the way out anyway, their final send-off! To give the old geezers a final Christan burial Aunt Abby & Martha had their nephew Teddy, who thinks he's the late President Teddy Roosevelt, bury them in the basement under the assumption that they, twelve as of last count, died from yellow fever in digging the Panama Canal! Digging it right there in the Brewster House in the heart of Brooklyn!If things weren't screwy enough already it's when Mortimer long lost brother an escapee from an Ohio mental institution for the criminally insane Jonathan, Raynond Massey, and his assistant Dr.Herman Einstein, Peter Loore, shows up that things really starts to get out of whack in the movie. Jonathan who, after a number of failed facial operations, looks like Boris Karloff's twin brother is on the lamb, after his escape from the mental institution, from the police after wracking up a total of twelve murders. What shocks Jonathan more then anything else, even his brother Mortiner, is that his two aunts Abby & Martha had killed as many people as he did! An even worse they did in all in one place, the Brewster house, where he committed his murders on four different continents!Mortimer who's trying to keep buried the fact that his two sweet and kindly aunts are in fact serial murderers slowly goes out of his mind with all the attempts he tries to keep the local police from finding that out. Jonathan who's got ideas of his own, in killing his hated brother Moritmer once and for all, also got a stiff Mr. Spanazio, a former associate of his who tried to double-cross him, to dispatch and there's only room for one left in the Brewster basement with it filled to capacity, twelve, and the latest victim being the one that his two aunts treated his last and final meal to!It's when Mortimer ends up getting tied up by Jonathan who plans to slowly dissect him, like a frog in a laboratory, that the calvary or police arrive to save his neck and all his other organs but the fact that he's related to such a bunch of nut cases like his two crazy aunts and delusional and murderous brothers Teddy and Jonathan has his own mental faculties become suspect! As well as Mortimer being slated to be committed to the Happy Dale Saniterium together with his crazy relieves!***SPOILERS*** That very pressing problem is settled in the final few minutes in the movie with Mortimer not only learning that he's not only sane, he's not a Brewster but the son of a ship' cook, which will not only keep him from being committed but won't keep him from marrying Ealine!

"Arsenic" is the filmed adaptation of the hugely successful Broadway play that starred Boris Karloff. Only John Alexander, in the epic role of Theodore "Teddy Roosevelt" Brewster, and Jean Adair and Josephine Hull as the maiden Aunts who preside over the Brewster home, reprise their roles from the play. But the remainder of the cast is perfect, even Raymond Massey replacing Karloff as the evil Jonathan Brewster.Cary Grant plays Mortimer Brewster, a drama critic who just got married on this Halloween day to the girl next door (across the cemetery, that is), Elaine Harper (Priscilla Lane). Stopping at home to collect their things for their honeymoon in Niagra Falls, Mortimer discovers that all sorts of unexpected things are going on that seriously interrupt his plans.This is one of the most frantic comedies ever filmed. One can only imagine how wonderful the stage version with the original cast must have been. Once Massey shows up with Dr. Einstein (Peter Lorre) in tow, things take off and never set down. Jack Carson is around for comic relief as a new beat police officer who is an aspiring writer, and Edward Everett Horton acts like a man who has gotten a little too close to his patients as the head of Happy Dale, the local sanitarium.Everybody in the cast has their moments. Teddy's charges up the stairway are legendary, as are his bugle blowing "to summon the cabinet." Priscilla Lane is charming as the spunky new bride who never does quite figure out the craziness going on next door. And Massey, with his comically dark portrayal, steals the show with his constant affront at people who keep saying that he "looks like Karloff." James Gleason brings a momentary element of sanity to the proceedings as the police Lieutenant who shows up towards the end, but the insanity of everyone else is positively infectious and he joins in the fun.While clearly a comedy, there are more serious elements thrown in for, well, relief. A brief conversation on the basement staircase between Jonathan and Dr. Einstein, in which Massey's looming shadow on the wall forms a brilliant counterpoint to the cringing Einstein, is a personal favorite. Artsy types might say that this is a "film noir comedy." Lorre gets off the immortal line there, "Oh no, not the Melvin method!" And every appearance by Miss Lane, who plays it straight throughout, is a treat. Such a shame that she retired so young.Highly recommended, one of the few must-sees in cinema. Best seen around Halloween. You can always find someone at work or play who has seen this and has a delighted reaction to share about it. At least, that's what I have found.

reviews.review_title: A hilarious mad cap comedy with intelligent screenwriting..
reviews.content:
Short Review :-Watched Arsenic And Old Lace (1944)A hilarious Mad cap comedy with intelligence screenwriting. Seems like Frank Capra wanted to have some so he made us laugh like mad guys by presenting this crazy comedy film. Every character in this film is purely mad whether it is Mortimer or his wife or those aunties or the doctor or horrible looking Jonathan but still film doesn't go downwards on the basis of quality. The major credit goes to the writer, dialogue writer and Screenwriter because the film is full of crazy conflicts, struggle and at last that much needed happy ending. And even that comes with a shocking yet funny suspense from past. The original Drama was adapted so quickly on screen therefore freshness did not fade away at the time of release and me watching this film after 76 years found it certainly funny. There isn't much to call for an acting, it's all about Screenplay and Direction. Frank Capra did a fantastic job and it was quite shocking to see such a hilarious ride coming in 1944 when Hollywood was doing not so great with comedies. Overall, Arsenic and Old Lace provides Fun in mad way like never before but you must enjoy the intellegence hidden in it's screenwriting.
Rating- 8/10*

reviews.review_title: Just When You Think It Can't Get Any Worse ...
reviews.content: This is truly one of THE funniest films I've ever seen. I'd rank it up there with The Out-Of-Towners and What's Up Doc? It's one of those silly, over-the-top comedies where a bad situation just keeps getting worse.Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant) is a famous author and journalist known for his anti-marriage views, but we are introduced to him down at city hall getting a marriage license! He gets hitched to the lovely Elaine Harper (Priscilla Lane) then they rush to share the good news with Mortimer's spinster aunts, and Elaine's father - a widowed preacher who lives across from Mortimer's family.Perhaps I should elaborate a bit ... Reverend Harper lives in a house across from the graveyard next to Brewster sisters dilapidated old house ... and it's Halloween!While sharing the news with his aunts Mortimer discovers a dead body in the house. He also discovers that his dear sweet elderly aunts are murderers ... and it all goes hysterically downhill from there.I don't want to give too much away because this is one of those films where it's better if you go into it knowing just the basics.I will say that some of the funniest gags take place off screen where you can hear what is happening and the rest is left to your imagination. I'll also say that Dr. Einstein (Peter Lorre) stole every scene he's in!And lastly, I'll say that this is a Must-See for any fan of classic cinema!

reviews.review_title: One of the best performances by one of the most under-rated actors.
reviews.content: Cary Grant, never won an Oscar.  A flagrant mistake by The Academy.  If we could go back and give Mr. Grant his due, several roles would doubtless come to mind, but the quintessential Mortimer Brewster of this film could only be played by Cary Grant.  His classic double-takes and frantic comic antics are unparalleled.  I find myself laughing out loud no matter how many times I have seen the film.  Truly one of the classic comedies.  I only regret that I cannot give it an 11.

Great movie. Cary Grant's facial expressions are perfect. I love Frank Capra and this is one of his best films.The cinematography is great, you feel like you're back in Brooklyn in the fall of the 1930s, about to drop off the edge of your world (one way or the other) if you walk into the Brewster house.This is an excellent blend of disparate characters, each with a personality unlike the other- except the two dear sisters-and my favorite was Peter Lorre, he struck me as the only sane one in the bunch, albeit on a poorly chosen road, to say the least.I would love to see this movie with someone who doesn't know what's coming. I actually never knew anyone who doesn't know the plot, and I think it must have been a powerfully funny situation before word got around.Oh well, all's well that ends well...except for those thirteen guys...

reviews.review_title: "And I'm Woodrow Wilson... So go to bed!"
reviews.content: This is Cary Grant at his funniest (and most energetic). It is a brilliant masterpiece of humor, combining the talents of the great Frank Capra, Cary Grant and Peter Lorre with the fantastic script from the Epsteins. There are several great one liners, and an insanely funny and twisted plot which somehow all falls into place by the end. One of the greats.

When I first read the description of this film, I thought it would never be something I would watch, let alone enjoy. However, after receiving a recommendation of this film, I decided to give "Arsenic and Old Lace" a try. I was pleasantly surprised. This movie actually proved to be one of the best comedies of its time. As with other great Cary Grant movies of this time, such as "Bringing Up Baby," this film was very fast-paced and got funnier as it went along. Despite the dark themes of old ladies poisoning people and a deformed man coming to their home, I found every minute of this film to be enjoyable and lighthearted. There are so many wisecracks and ironic moments, such as Cary Grant talking about the bad guys tying him up just as they are about to do so. The pace never slows down for a minute and keeps us engaged throughout. Don't hesitate to see this movie because of the black comedy nature of the film. If you've been wondering if this is worthwhile or how it could possibly be funny, I suggest you give it a try. I found "Arsenic and Old Lace" hilarious and worthy of my time.***1/2 out of ****

reviews.review_title: A classic that is well worth watching
reviews.content: This movie was based of a play of the same name, though the play must have been written after 1932 as there is a comment on a second Roosevelt becoming president, but more on that later. This movie is described as a classic, I just think it is absolutely hilarious. There is so much in this movie that makes it great though to really appreciate the comedy you need to watch the movie. After seeing this I have decided that Frank Capra is one of the greatest directors: both this and Mr Smith Goes to Washington are brilliant movies, and his comedy is in such away that it is hilarious without being rude, crude, or simply stupid. One thing about the comedy in this movie is the way that Carey Grant is so animated. His facial expressions are something that must be seen rather than talked about, and the comedy in this movie is very visual. Some of the scenes in this movie that I like are the poor cab driver left waiting outside for the entire night and at one stage he is asked to hail a cab, which he does, before he realises that he is a cab driver. (Hey, I reckon I ought to play the cab driver! I wonder if it is in the original play). Another are the subtle political jokes about Teddy Roosevelt. The Brewster household are basically nuts and one of them thinks he is Teddy Roosevelt, which leads to a lot of interesting comments, especially if you know about American History. Capra has constructed this movie as if it were the stage play. While watching it, you feel as if you are watching the play. Only the first two minutes are removed from the play, so I believe. Capra has done a very good job at it though. The BBC versions of the Shakespeare plays are similarly done but turn out really poorly. Arsenic and Old Lace could be viewed by a live studio audience. One thing that the movie raises is the question of euthanasia. It wasn't really a question back then, and is joked about as in this movie, but now it is very topical. The old ladies think that it is okay, but their son, Mortimer, is horrified, while John is shocked that they have killed as many people as he has. The movie is does not have the ladies prosecuted for this act, but it emphasizes that it is murder. Mortimer ends up committing the ladies to the mental institute. They do not get away free. Another interesting thing about the movie is the name of the sons. The evil son has a normal name, John, while the good son has a rather sinister name, Mortimer. Arsenic and Old Lace is a classic movie and deserves all the rave that it receives. I loved the movie and others that I have spoken to are just as thrilled about it. I have been approached about doing it as a play, and now that I think of it, I would love to do it.

reviews.review_title: A good sense of humor from Capra helps the outrageous "Arsenic"
reviews.content: Few classic era film directors did comedy better than Frank Capra, if any. The over-the-top ridiculous dark comedy farce "Arsenic and Old Lace" is not the three-time Oscar winner's usual cup of tea (there's an inherent lack of romance), but he captures the adaptation of the play with a sense of humor that's critical for a story so ridiculous.Having seen the play myself, admittedly the comic twists and sheer outrageousness of some of the characters was less effective upon a second viewing, but it doesn't detract from comprehending the comic genius of Joseph Kesselring's original script. The moral of the story is that everyone's crazy. Period."Arsenic" takes place in one afternoon and night in Brooklyn, where esteemed theatre critic and self-proclaimed marriage-hater Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant) has taken refuge with his dear old aunts before taking off on his honeymoon with Elaine Harper (Priscilla Lane), a fact he's publicly ashamed of. Not long into his stay, however, he discovers both sweet Aunt Abby (Josephine Hull) and Aunt Martha (Jean Adair) are in fact mercy killers who poison lonely old men without families and homes and bury them in the basement with the aid of Mortimer's delusional brother, Teddy, who believes he's Teddy Roosevelt. In an effort to sort it all out, Mortimer drives himself practically insane.I've never had a bad thing to say about him, but this is a fine piece of total overacting by Grant. Part of it is the charm story and Capra's vision to acknowledge its absurdity, but from his first discovery of the body in the window seat, Grant is up and over-the-top. It takes a bit away from the momentum, neglecting a steady accumulation of craziness, even if that's not the film's intention. Grant is much better in charming romantic roles and not as an all- out comedian, but he has some quality moments.Capra's creativity was no doubt limited by the confines of the story. It almost entirely takes place inside the Brewster home (convenient for the play, just not the movie). The Epsteins' adaptation takes some liberties where possible, but it's merely wiggle-room. The director leaves his mark in moments when the story hits a peak in terms of the physical humor. He also films some comically dark scenes when Mortimer's loony brother Jonathan (Raymond Massey) returns with his accomplice Dr. Einstein (wonderful character actor Peter Lorre). Those two actors add more dimension to their performances which helps the film be taken a tad more seriously.Amidst the chaos, however, "Arsenic and Old Lace" has a truthful ring to it. Sanity is a relative attribute and we should be so lucky as to possess it in the slightest bit. "Arsenic" doesn't feel like some of the '30s and '40s classics before it, but it's great fun and a real laugh. Who says every film has to be totally sane and by-the-book?~Steven CVisit my site http://moviemusereviews.com

reviews.review_title: Both Ahead of Its Time and Markedly Of Its Time
reviews.content: Frank Capra has put into this picture all of the rowdy slapstick, tender innocence and patent melodrama from the original material. That he adds a handful of filmic jaunts, however, doesn't do much good or add any punch. The movie opens on a montage about peculiar and random Brooklyn, and fosters the chuckle along with a riot scene at Ebbets Field, a scene which has no perceptible basis for being in the movie at all. From there it switches to a high-octane schmaltz sequence in the marriage license bureau, where above all things, people are getting marriage licenses, Cary Grant and Priscilla Lane among them. Then there's another sequence of elaborate chasing and necking in a Brooklyn cemetery, and, at last, guess what, the story of Arsenic and Old Lace. All the same, in the long run, these filmic additions give impact to the farce with Aunts Abby and Martha in the house, because beginning so schmaltzy and mawkish makes such ink-black humor so much more unexpected.This unconventional patchwork is distinct from most of the other "reform-minded Capra-corn" films with social principles that became his brand, like It's a Wonderful Life, Meet John Doe, or Mr. Smith Goes to Washington. It's more similar in tone to his screwball romantic comedy It Happened One Night and to Capra's other adaptation from a Broadway play You Can't Take It With You. Playing theatre critic Mortimer Brewster---frankly it doesn't matter, it's fine just viewing him for his star power the whole time---Cary Grant accomplishes a stunning mission of overstated acting with remarkable double-takes, slapstick and overall bewilderment. What makes his performance so effective is that in essence he plays the straight man in a house crammed with eccentrics, yet it is his relentless mugging and other facial agility that make you laugh. Naturally it's all exaggerated from top to bottom, but that's what the role demands and he succeeds in peddling the motor for all the farce happening around him.Not that Grant is the lone one to get laughs in this combination of slapstick and fast-paced jousting. Played impeccably by veteran stage actress Josephine Hull and Canadian vaudevillian Jean Adair, the doting aunts' account of how they routinely murder gentleman visitors is really my favorite part, by far. After telling Grant how they add Arsenic, Strychnine, and "just a pinch of" Cyanide to Elderberry wine because it makes tea taste bitter, they smugly add that one of the gentlemen even found time to say how nice it tasted before he died. John Alexander is hilarious in his unquestionably most memorable performance as Grant's brother Teddy, who believes he's Teddy Roosevelt to the extent that his behavior, dress and perception of his surroundings all correspond with defining aspects of the vividly inimitable American president. Another of my favorite elements is how old Abby and Martha delight in using Teddy's belief that he's digging the Panama Canal to bury their shocking amount of dead bodies in the basement.Ahead of its time? OK, but it is also markedly of its time, and has stood the test of time to stay as witty today as anything Hollywood is producing now. Our reactions to inconsistencies, oddities, unanticipated discrepancies with normalcy and established ranks will differ in terms of particular circumstances. The established rule we hear vintage comedians talk about is that if the incongruity works in a context where it's foreboding, it'll dispose us toward a fearful response, but if the framework is one that's marked as non-threatening, where the prospect of harm and dread has been denied, the circumstances are apt for humor. I've rarely found this notion better substantiated than in the characters of Aunt Martha and Aunt Abby, whose descriptions of their serial murders are so sweet and innocent that they couldn't be less congruous.

This is one movie that should be seen at least once by everyone.  It proves, once and for all that a big, humongus budget is *not nessesary* to make a good movie!! Cary plays the best strait man that I've ever seen when he discovers just what is going on in his aunt's house. (yikes!)  And then his long lost brother shows up with evil intents! Peter Loree was great as well,, the movie starts off with 2 sisters living in this old house with their brother who thinks it's San Juan Hill and he plays a bugle too.
