'Arsenic and Old Lace' is a very entertaining movie.  It goes by very quickly and is generally always interesting.  However, there is some over acting in the film, specifically from Cary Grant, whose gestures are a little over the top at some points.  Even then, he is still quite funny at many points.  I was surprised by some of the darker elements of this movie, most notably Mortimer Brewster's(Grant) brother Jonathan.  The movie(or play for that matter)takes a rather dark twist upon the arrival of his character.  I was not expecting it to be dark at all.  The running Boris Karloff joke was quite amusing though.The best thing of all though are Moritimer's aunts.  They are easily to most memorable and enjoyable characters in the movie.  Seemingly so innocent, and really they have no bad intentions at all.  They are happy Mortimer fell in love, scared of Jonathan and so forth.  They are the best thing in the movie, and unfortunately aren't in it quite enough.  The other characters really aren't anything special.  The bumbling police force, Mortimer's crazy brother that thinks he is Teddy Roosevelt and Jonathans friend, Dr.Einstein, are all underused a bit and at times irritating.  Most underused however is Priscilla Lane, who plays Mortimer's new wife.  She is hardly anywhere to be found, and its a shame because I would have liked to have seen more of her as well.Even with all the extra stock characters, and a mad cap ending that seems to last a bit to long, this movie is still worth watching.  At least you should watch it to see the two innocent old women.  They are great characters.  I know I'll never look at little old women the same way again.  7 out of 10.

I am baffled, BAFFLED, by the high rating of this film.  I thought it was awful.  I know Cary Grant can do screwball comedy--see Bringing up Baby and the Philadelphia Story--but his performance here was laughable, and unfortunately not in the way intended.  He was bad.  He was stiff.  His timing was five hundred miles off.  I blame Frank Capra, who didn't seem to be able to pull this story together.  All his characters seemed to be acting in their own separate films, most of them badly.  And it was all so forced and so stagy.  I felt like I was stuck in that room with a bunch of loud hammy actors running around.Peter Lorre was good, though, and the two aunts, and I did enjoy the surrealist strangeness of it all.  I love laughing at murder, for some reason.  I think this film could have worked well with a different director and different lead, and maybe a few re-writes to some of the more ludicrous plot points.  Bob Hope was originally supposed to play Cary Grant's part, and I think he would have been way better in the role.  Some of the dialogue felt like it was written for him, and I could well picture him delivering it.  I could also see this film working really well as an Ealing Studios production, the obnoxiousness turned down a notch, and the strangeness cranked up, and maybe with Alec Guinness playing the villainous brother.Priscilla Lane had one of the sexiest mouths in cinema history.  Saucy lips and a sly tongue.  Just a really good, kissable mouth.  Always an enjoyable addition to a film.Overall, probably the worst Capra film I have seen, and a lesser screwball comedy.  5/10.
Cary Grant's facial expressions make this movie an unforgettable experience. Also this movie contains so many good jokes.

reviews.review_title: A lack of Boris is upsetting
reviews.content:
When this production was first considered for filming, the play was still having a successful run on Broadway.   Boris Karloff took the role of Jonathan Brewster based on one line of dialogue. this When Dr. Einstein asked, "Johnny.  Why did you kill that man?  He was being nice and he gave us a ride," to which the Jonathan Brewster character answered, "Because he said I looked like Boris Karloff.     Herein lies my problem with this motion picture. Mr. Karloff was asked to stay with the play, and not the role went to Raymond Massey, who looks very little like Boris Karloff, and was a poor substitute for the horror legend. Besides, Karloff delivering the line is far funnier than any other actor delivering the same line. This is not to say that I don't like the movie, but whenever Massey comes on screen I have to imagine dear Boris doing the scenes with the wonderful Mr. Peter Lorre, so this does hurt the film for me at those moments.     Strangely enough, Cary Grant thought this was his worst film performance, and I really don't get that.     I remember being blown away by his impeccable timing and over-the-top, yet fitting performance as the beleaguered theater critic Mortimer Brewster. What's funny is that he seems to be the least same member of this family.
    Another footnote: Warner Bros. made agreement with the the theater productions' producers that they would not released the film until after the Broadway show had completed its run, even though the film was made while the show was still onstage.     As a sort of consolation prize, Karloff and Lorre played similar roles in a forgettable Kay Keyser B movie, "The Boogie Man Will Get You." Capra convinced Warners that the film was do-able because of the low cost using some standing sets and that much of the Broadway actors could be bought for a song. The only real cost was the price tag for Cary Grant's acting services, and that was a guaranteed box-office draw anyway, so the production was a done deal.    The key members of the cast were the very same actors that appeared in the original play, with the exception of Edgar Stehli as Dr. Harry Einstein and Alyn Joslyn as Mortimer. (I believe Jack Carson was a contract player at Warners anwyay, and most likely was NOT in the play either.) I don't see Stehli being anywhere near as perfectly cast as was Lorre, and I know that Cary Grant beats Joslyn in a walk as a comedic actor, not to mention that Joslyn was never leading-man material anyway. But these changes make sense.    Anyway, the casting of Raymond Massey is the only flaw I can see in this otherwise fabulously funny motion picture.

reviews.review_title: A hilarious comedy with a serial twist
reviews.content: Cary Grant at his best in this hilarious two-hour comedy! Mortimer Brewstor has just been married when he discovers that his two kindly old aunts are killers. Throughout the film, he has to deal with a worried wife, a sinister brother who looks like Boris Karloff, an evil doctor, and laughs all the way. His brother's a nut case who thinks he's Theodore Roosevelt, and insists on charging up the staircase. All in all, a 4-star film!!

reviews.review_title: Insanity Runs In My Family......It Practically Gallops.
reviews.content: During his lifetime, if anyone had asked Cary Grant about his performance in Arsenic & Old Lace, he would have declared it one of his least favourite film roles AND also his least favourite on screen performance. However, if you ask any Cary Grant fan their views on the movie and the vote will be unanimously contradictory to Mr Grant's own sentiments.Frank Capra had seen Joseph Kesselring's black screwball comedy farce on the Broadway stage in 1941 and immediately set about procuring the movie rights. The movie was actually filmed in late 1941 but not released until 1944 to allow the play to finish it's Broadway run, so audiences couldn't compare the play to it's screen counterpart. (And potentially diminish Box Office returns).Grant plays Mortimer Brewster a newlywed drama critic who before embarking on his honeymoon with his bride Elaine, (played by the delectable Pricilla Lane), visits his two maiden aunts in Brooklyn to give them the good news.Aunt Abby, (Josephine Hull), and Aunt Martha, (Jean Adair), are two kind hearted pillars of the Society, who regularly invite the local Reverend to tea, they give old toys to the local children's home and help the police benevolent fund whenever possible. Sounds perfect doesn't it? However their demeanour hides a darker secret. They're murderers whose body count is already into double figures. However, they are not hardened mob assassins and neither are they psychopaths. They innocently poison lonely, sad passers-by with their home made elderberry wine. These are not random killings either, their victims have to meet a certain criteria. They only kill gentlemen that have no family, home, money or prospects. They see their killings as an act of mercy by helping these poor people find the peace in death that has been so cruelly denied them in life. How sweet.Mortimer has a brother Teddy, another harmless nutter who believes himself to be President Theodore Roosevelt who's digging the Panama Canal in their cellar and whenever his Aunt's present him with another body to bury in the cellar, simply assumes that Yellow Fever has claimed them. Quite a normal assumption I suppose...if you think you're in Panama.As luck would have it, Mortimers other and dangerously psychotic brother Jonathan, (Raymond Massey), also returns home to Brooklyn that night on the run from the law and he's not alone. His German plastic surgeon Dr Einstein, (Peter Lorre), is with him, and just to blend in, they've brought a corpse of their own to the party.Mortimer now believes that insanity is hereditary in his family and that he too will one day becomes as mad as a box of frogs. However his immediate concern is to figure out how to save his aunt's and his brother Teddy from either life imprisonment or the chair, a situation not made easier, as Jonathan already has plans to make him the next body that Teddy buries in the cellar.The script is fast and furious and the acting from ALL is superb, and Grants facial expressions are legendary.Black Comedy was never better than this.Enjoy!!!

reviews.review_title: Simply charming . and VERY funny (some spoilers)
reviews.content: I must first say that, although I have read that Cary Grant was unhappy with his role in this film, he should be well proud of himself.  Yes, he overplays it a little, but when you consider the material and the fact that the movie is a comedy, it is just such a perfect performance.  The fact that Mortimer is afraid that he will also end up as nutty as all of these relatives of his only adds to the poor man's neurosis, and makes him paranoid on top of being afraid and bewildered by the day's events, and Grant is magnificent in portraying all of these emotions and conflicts at once.  I can't see anyone else in the role - it belongs to Grant completely.THE BEST RUNNING GAG IN MOVIE HISTORY:  What can I say about the `he looks like Boris Karloff' gag except that it's so damn funny that I laughed every single time, or when Jack Carson says, `hey look at that puss,' or when Grant calls him `handsome.'  And Jonathan's baby photo and talk of it scaring children at Halloween .!!! All of this was just hilarious.  Hats off to Massey, and as much as I like Boris Karloff, and I'm sure he'd have been great in the role, it's simply funnier that the guy LOOKS LIKE KARLOFF!Another fun and oh-so-true-to-life running joke: People in all sorts of situations barraging Mortimer with their play/novel ideas because he is a writer -- even, a couple of times, when their lives clearly were in danger.I love the many, MANY throw-away lines that were tossed off so matter-of-factly by the stellar cast (especially Grant), but my favorite must be when the cat comes out of the body-strewn basement and Grant remarks, `even the cat's in on it.'  Oh, man, I'm laughing just typing this.John Alexander was delightful as President Roosevelt, and it was funny to picture that `he wouldn't be anybody' when the aunts persuaded him to be George Washington, and simply hid under the bed.Priscilla Lane was great as always, even though her role was pretty thankless for the most part. James Gleason was terrific as the cop, Jack Carson was funny beyond compare, Everett Horton was his usually silly self, and the aunts wonderfully underplayed their roles.Peter Lorre, one of my favorite actors, was such a trip as the `short, balding bug-eyed' Dr. Einstein, and Raymond Massey was an absolute hoot as Jonathan.Hands down, my favorite comedy ever.  DO NOT MISS THIS ONE, folks!!!

I think, Arsenic and old lace is the most wonderful screwball comedy I've ever seen. The actors are simply terrific, especially Cary Grant, who is in his best. The dialogues are sparkling, and when you have started to laugh, you wouldn't be able to stop. I have seen it many times, and I have never grown tired of it. It is a must-see.

reviews.review_title: A classic motion picture that is absolutely CRAZY!
reviews.content: Directed by Frank Capra, with a well-written screenplay by the Epstein brothers and a fantastically haunting music score by Max Steiner, "Arsenic and Old Lace" is an outrageous Hallowe'en comedy. The star of this picture is none other than the slick, fast-talking Cary Grant, who is full of wild & unpredictable humor as drama critic Mortimer Brewster, literally bending over backwards in order to cover up the lethal peculiarities of his two otherwise dear & sweet aunts (Josephine Hull and Jean Adair). Costarring is Raymond Massey as Mortimer's long-lost brother Jonathan, whose grim demeanor might be a little too dark for such a lighthearted comedy. Jonathan's hideously scarred face can be blamed on the bumbling, intoxicated plastic surgeon Dr. Einstein (Peter Lorre). Not to mention John Alexander as another one of Mortimer's demented brothers who believes himself to be Teddy Roosevelt, repeatedly charging up the staircase as if it were San Juan Hill; and Jack Carson as police officer O'Hara, who delightfully tells Mortimer about a play he has written while Mortimer is literally tied up and gagged! Certainly, this movie bears the resemblance of a stage play, from which, in fact, it is based.Aside from what I have already mentioned, here are some of my other favorite highlights from "Arsenic and Old Lace." Mortimer has an unforgettable look on his face when he discovers the body in the window seat. He is also hilarious as he tries unsuccessfully to get the telephone operator to contact the Happy Dale Sanitaruim and as he stops an elderly gentleman from being poisoned by a drink. The opening chaotic baseball sequence (the Brooklyn Dodgers vs. the New York Yankees) is memorable, even though it has nothing to do with the rest of the film. In order to divert the policemen's attention from the thirteen bodies in the cellar, Mortimer pretends to act crazy, such as by running around while gagged & tied to a chair and by charging up the staircase with Teddy's bugle. And finally, Mortimer devises a brilliant little word game to convince Teddy that the word "Brewster" is code for "Roosevelt." "Arsenic and Old Lace" is a truly wild & wacky movie, no question about it whatsoever! It does have a happy ending but, as Frank Capra Jr. once stated, you gotta pay for a happy ending! Amidst all of the various oddball characters, this film raises the question of who is mentally stable and who isn't, as confirmed by the cab driver (Garry Owen) at the very end of the movie: "I'm not a cab driver! I'm a coffeepot!"

reviews.review_title: They Don't Make The Like This Anymore.
reviews.content: I hate to use that tired old cliché but it really is true. Cary Grant really shines in this black comedy as the nephew of two aunts whose hobby killing of lonely old men who are interested in a room at their home. Grants Mortimer Brewster is the perfection of comic timing. Josephine Hull and Jean Adair make the perfect dawdling aunts. Add in Raymond Massey and Peter Lorre and there is little in this film not to like,John Alexander is great as Mortimer's brother Theodore who thinks he is Teddy Roosevelt. The aunts have him in Panama, the basement, digging locks to bury their kills in. The action is frantic and seldom boring. For its time this film was cutting edge.If you are the least bit interested in classic films the this is a must view. It will be on just about every film buffs top ten list, as well it should be.

reviews.review_title: I suspect it works better as a play
reviews.content: It's a comedy set on Halloween Day in Brooklyn, New York, around 1940. It follows a newly-married drama critic who learns his family includes multiple serial killers.Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant) was a prominent bachelor drama critic in New York who wrote books decrying marriage. However, he has fallen in love and, earlier in the day, married Elaine Harper (Priscilla Lane), the daughter of the minister who lives across a cemetery from his aunt's home. His aunts, Abby (Josephine Hull) and Martha (Jean Adair), seem sweet and model citizens. They live with Mortimer's brother, Teddy (John Alexander), who fancies himself to be President Teddy Roosevelt. Mortimer discovers a body in the house and immediately works to get Teddy sent to a sanitarium for the mentally ill.Then Mortimer's other brother, Jonathan (Raymond Massey), suddenly arrives with his accompanying Doctor Einstein (Peter Lorre). Jonathan has had multiple surgeries to change his face and now resembles Boris Karloff. Jonathan and Doctor Einstein have their own murderous secrets.Mortimer tries to sort out the rapidly increasing chaos, and incompetent Brooklyn police provide little aid. Fortunately, it happily resolves by the end.I was really disappointed by the movie. It's basic slapstick, at least as played by Cary Grant and seemed to try too hard. Grant was shouting throughout the film, and many other characters seemed too over the top. I suspect "Arsenic and Old Lace" works better as a play than as a movie.

Then, they have a nephew, who thinks to be Theodore Roosevelt and another one (Raymond Massey, which is like Boris Karloff, thanks to the make up), who is just escaped from the prison. In all this strange group of people, arrives Mortimer (Cary Grant)with his  future bride (Priscilla Lane, nice but not necessary to the story). The humour is exceptional with a lot of great actors (Alexander, Horton, Lorre the others) and it is a funny but not too much valued work by Capra.

I am *shocked* at how many people commenting are panning this fantastic film, where are the folks who made up the overall 8/10 rating?Anyway, this is the kind of movie that no one is making anymore, and is a hallmark of the "Golden Age" - bubbly and sweet on the surface, but dark and demented underneath. In fact that's pretty much the theme of the movie itself - the persona we show to the world never tells the whole story. Staunch bachelors are true romantics, pastors daughters are sex kittens (*subtly* suggested of course), cops are playwrights, and sweet old aunties are... well, you'll see. (But truly evil people seem to be pretty much grotesque inside and out - does that add or detract to my theory?)First off, the film is *&$#ing funny. Cary Grant is brilliant, and anyone who thinks he is overacting or over the top simply doesn't get this particular brand of comedy. The aunts are absolutely adorable and seriously sick. The fabulously choreographed physical frenzy is matched by the fabulously choreographed quick-witted and often overlapping dialogue. And the real villains are *genuinely* frightening and disturbing. I've seen this film maybe 5 or 6 times, and I'm always a little shocked by just how dark it really is. It's not a perfect movie, of course, but film geeks like me can hardly ever see a movie without picking it apart while we're watching it - and I can honestly say I am always totally taken in by this one every time I watch it.You poor people who think this flick is all treacle don't recognize the bitter taste underneath - and then it's too late, so sad...

reviews.review_title: One of funniest of all times
reviews.content: I've watched this film many times over the years and it never grows old. But with a witty script and an ensemble of terrific character actors who needs anything more. Amazingly, this movie didn't receive a single Oscar nomination!

What would you do if you found out that your own dear aunts were homicidal maniacs? There's a variety of ways to deal with the situation but Cary Grant probably picks the most unorthodox and unconventional solutions in Arsenic and Old Lace, a classic Frank Capra comedy from 1944. Grant stars as Mortimer Brewster, a drama critique who, at the opening of the film, marries his girlfriend. He goes home to tell his aunts and prepare for his honeymoon to Niagra Falls. However, while at home he finds out his aunts have poisoned twelve men over the past few months and they are all buried in the cellar. This news sends Mortimer racing around trying to hide the fact that his aunts are homicidal, while also dealing with a variety of other problems as this kind of insanity runs in his family. At the same time as he is dealing with his aunts Mortimer has one brother who thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt and another a deformed serial killer who, after being gone for twenty years, decides to return home at the most inopportune time. It's a wild and bizarre ride that is chock full of innocently delightful laughs.Arsenic and Old Lace represents the Golden Age of the American comedy. Some of the most classic comedies were made during World War II in order to ease the troubled times America was involved in. Arsenic and Old Lace falls right in with these films, having been released in 1944. Therefore, it's only purpose is just to make us laugh. It aims to entertain and delight, and I would say it does just that. It's got a cavalcade of wacky and eccentric characters played by a fantastic cast of hilarious actors and actresses. The duo of Aunt Abby and Aunt Martha is one of the most hilarious on screen pairings I've ever seen and the two actresses, Josephine Hull and Jean Adair respectively, play the part so perfectly. They come off as the sweetest old ladies you could ever meet who just don't understand what all the fuss is about concerning the twelve dead bodies they have buried in their cellar. It's certainly comedy at its most intelligent.The whole point of Arsenic and Old Lace is to be incredibly weird in a very entertaining way. And that is definitely what it does. This is a very strange film with all sorts of moments that make you scratch your head in confusion and chuckle at the same time. It's an incredibly offbeat film for its time, and this adds to the humor. As far as comedy goes this isn't quite my cup of tea, but I have the utmost respect for what a quality comedy film this is. Personally my taste leans towards more modern comedy stilings, but Arsenic and Old Lace is representative of a great era of comedy and just film in general. It's a great film that shouldn't be missed.

reviews.review_title: Definite inspiration for the modern day dark comedy
reviews.content: This is definitely the most off the wall and bizarre film that I have ever seen involving Cary Grant and very against type for it's era..Grant was great as usual in this very different setting.The film,I believe helped set the stage for the dark comedies to come in the modern era.I love how the two elderly spinsters are totally oblivious to the fact that they are doing wrong and Grant's discovery and reaction to this.Each character is colorful in his or her own way and lends much to the story.Most who are absorbed in modern film without much experience in watching older era films might take offense in regards to mental illness being used for laughs here,but it was a different time and that must be taken into consideration.Raymond Massey and Peter Lorre do a great job of lending a horror film touch in the middle of the laughs..I like it!

reviews.review_title: So Good You Can Almost Smell the Apple Cider!
reviews.content: Whenever it gets to be close to October, I start to reminisce of Halloween with its (Cool brisk air, Apple Cider, Pumpkins, Spooky Decorations), and of course all the great television Specials I enjoyed as child.......... Who am I kidding? I still enjoy them. Thank God for DVDs and Videos.Of all the Halloween Specials and Movies I have seen the best I think by far is Frank Capra's  `Arsenic and Old Lace' 1944. I bought the DVD release and must say it never gets old. I know all the criticisms for this movie, Cary Grant's Double Takes, The weak script, The over acting. To all the negative critics I say `LIGHTEN-UP'. You have to take this movie for what it is.  A Frank Capra 1940 Movie Classic.The movie is closely based on the hugely successful Broadway play. Cary Grant plays Mortimer Brewster a dramatic critic who's written many books about the pitfalls of marriage. The movie takes place on Halloween night. And starts with Grant getting married.  Together he and his new wife Elaine played by Priscilla Lane go tell his two aunts (who raised him from birth) about is marriage. What he finds is that his spinster Aunts are in fact Serial Killers and have been poisoning lonely old gentlemen and burying them in their basement. Its what they call their charity. This sets Grant in to a whirlwind of double take after double take. When you add his 2 brothers Teddy (who thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt) and Jonathan (Mortimer's Lunatic murdering brother) to the mix you get a Madcap Halloween Romp that with tickle your funny bone! Or as Teddy says in the movie `BULLY', ` DELIGHTFUL'!

Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant) knows that his family is eccentric, but after discovering that his spinster aunts have been murdering gentlemen and burying them in the cellar, he comes to realize that his entire family is insane.Taken directly from the stage, complete with several original cast members, this remains one of the most important films in the history of cinema. Loaded with zany characters, absurd situations and biting satire, "Arsenic and Old Lace" is the granddaddy of black comedies. Decades before Kevin Williamson wrote "Scream" and Joe Dante made any of his films, Joseph Kesserling loaded this production with self-referential inside jokes and comedy that paved the way for films that followed  films that ranged from "The Trouble with Harry" to "Heathers" and beyond.The production values are slick but modest  the majority of scenes play out in the Brewster sisters' sitting room, though with the outlandish goings on, one hardly notices how stagy it appears. The cast is near perfection, and appeared to have been having as much fun as the viewers. Peter Lorre is a particular standout as the creepy cohort of Jonathan Brewster (sadly, Boris Karloff, who originated the role of Jonathan on the stage was not contractually allowed to reprise it in the film  but Raymond Massey is a more than adequate replacement). Frank Capra's direction is on-the-ball every time, undoubtedly focusing on the greatest moments as he saw them on the stage. A five-star film in every way, "Arsenic and Old Lace" is a must-see for all lovers of dark humored comedies.

When I see the types of comedies being made today, I grow despondent. The quick wit that once ruled the comedy film is all but vanished, having been replaced with crude one-liners about bodily functions and sex. Thankfully, I can always turn back to the movies of the Golden Age and laugh at the pratfalls and the double-takes."Arsenic and Old Lace" is an excellent example of one of those fine old movies. Just about everyone in this film is wonderfully hilarious and spot on in their comedic timing. The jokes are superb and the double-takes always bring a smile to my face. Every role with played with unforgettable style and panache (although I sometimes wish that Boris Karloff had been available to play Johnathan in the movie as he did in the play). If you, like me, can't take one more viewing of "American Pie" or "40 Year Old Virgin", this is an excellent (and vastly superior) alternative. Thank you, Mr. Grant, for this cinematic diamond.

reviews.review_title: An all time, top ten best selection
reviews.content: The best comedy made. Just edges out "His Girl Friday" for the honor.Capra used the sound stage to its advantage in bringing this play to the screen. Always fresh and funny regardless of the times viewed.Worthy of a semester in any film study course.

Cary Grant steals the show, but there are also great performances by Raymond Massey, Jack Carson and the two aunts, Josephine Hull and Jean Adair. Not one moment goes by without a hilarious line or scene. Timeless plot. Everyone over 5 years old can enjoy it.

This movie cracked me up!  I think I saw the play as a child but this was my first time seeing the movie.  Cary Grant was an absolute nut!  And a cute one to boot!  The direction, supporting players, everything was A-1.  Too bad this whole crew isn't still around today.  They could teach the present film industry crowd a lot.

reviews.review_title: The Unsung Heroine of Arsenic and Old Lace
reviews.content: Much has been written about Arsenic and Old Lace, with its various characters and performances. But the true spark of this film is, in my humble opinion, Priscilla Lane.Not only is she as beautiful as any actress of the 1940s, she also more than holds her own up against Cary Grant's manic performance.Underutilized in this film and rarely mentioned in reviews and articles about Arsenic and Old Lace, Priscilla Lane brings an inviting warmth and energy to her scenes with Cary Grant that is sorely missed when she is off screen.All in all Arsenic and Old Lace is a fun movie that could have been much better with a few changes here and there.It seems like the same could be said about a lot of movies, doesn't it?

I watched this DVD and I while I don't rate it as highly as the rest of the IMDB community I must say I was impressed with Cary Grant. The facial expressions, the vocalizations, the gestures, the timing were all perfect on his part. Peter Lorre (Mr. Cairo in The Maltese Falcon) is also memorable. Perhaps it was the mood I was in at the time, but I found the story ridiculous. I know it was supposed to be a dark comedy but I rarely found any of the shenanigans, especially those of the little old ladies, anything more than marginally amusing. I wish Ms. Lane could've had more screen time. I became extra attentive whenever she was onscreen. I think the reason I don't rate this film as highly as most people is that it simply isn't my cup of tea. Obviously the filmmakers impressed the vast majority. My score: 6/10.

reviews.review_title: A Comedy That Will Kill You With Laughter
reviews.content: Frank Capra's Arsenic and Old Lace is one of the best comedies I've ever seen, combining slapstick, screwball, silent film antics and sharp dialogue to produce a gem of a movie.Cary Grant plays Mortimer Brewster, a drama critic who's just married. Before leaving to the Niagara Falls on honeymoon, he pays a visit to his elderly aunts in Brooklyn. It should have been a normal day, but there's nothing normal in the Brester abode. His mad brother thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt, Mortimer finds out his aunts are serial killers poisoning lonely old men and burying them in the cellar, with proper religious service and fresh flowers on Sunday included; and to cap it all, his deranged brother Jonathan, who looks like Boris Karloff in Frankstein (this isn't my comparison; this is a running gag in the movie), has ran away from the hospital for the criminally insane along with a plastic surgeon who'll operate on his face.In the middle of all this, Mortimer has to find a way to commit Teddy, get rid of Jonathan and Dr. Einstein, and keep his aunts out of jail. What follows is a movie full of wit, twists and lots and lots of humor, from the darkest to the sweetest.The entire cast is to be praised, but of course the real star is Cary Grant, one of the greatest actors, comedy and otherwise, the world ever saw. He delivers a performance that is just as memorable for its physical, over-the-top behavior as it is for his quirky dialogue.Finally, the brothers Julius and Philip Epstein deserve credit for the adaptation of the Broadway play the movie is based on. No strangers to witty dialogue, I'm sure the writers of Casablanca had a lot to do with the movie being so marvellous.

reviews.review_title: Cary Grant doing Daffy Duck. Oh, yeah and a lot of Boris Karloff jokes.
reviews.content: Despite the fact that this is a very entertaining and sometimes hilarious movie, you somehow can't get over the misguided over the top performance of Cary Grant.Grant was the very epitome of the sophisticated, cool gentleman with a very dry sense of humour. Here, he is called upon to be manic and shocked at everything he hears. Everything he says has an question mark + an exclamation point behind it.Now for the good part. Peter Lorre as Dr. Einstein. Lorre was famous for his kind of nervous, fidgety persona and to this day, he is still the subject of parody, especially in cartoons. His performance as Dr. Einstein is almost like seeing a live action incarnation of those parodies, although his characters were never that insane.The two little old ladies are also very well played by two actresses who were not that well known in movies, although one of them, Josephine Hull, became somewhat famous because of this part and one in Harvey with James Stewart.And of course who can forget the supremely crazy performance by John Alexander as Teddy. It is hard to imagine an actor playing such a character today but Alexander never breaks the wall and let the audience know that he is in on the joke.The many references to Boris Karloff are only funny to people who know either the movie Frankenstein or that Karloff played the part of Jonathan Brewster on stage, but it gets a big laugh for any movie buff every time. There are too many memorable characters to mention and that's the reason why it's still a joy to watch, even after nearly 70 years since it was made. It is also a shame that the director Frank Capra is mostly known for his message pictures like Mr. Smith and Mr. Deeds because he certainly nailed the comedy in this one.So if you can ignore Grant's mugging and suspend disbelief of the rather insane story, you will have a fabulous time. Too bad, comedies like this are a thing of the past.

reviews.review_title: I laughed at some scenes and was plain baffled at others
reviews.content: This has to have been one of the weirdest screwball comedies I've seen in my life.  Only Frank Kapra could take something this chaotic and make it work. As the story went on it just got weirder and weirder, and it pulled me in even more.  This by far has to be one of my favorite classic movies, but I can't tell you how many times I've been tempted to yell charge while running up a flight of steps after seeing this. 10/10.

Lighten up, put yourself in 1944 and enjoy!  This hilarious movie is meant to be taken lightly.  Enjoy the mugging and outlandish acting that you aren't used to seeing from Cary Grant.  Enjoy some of the best performances ever from some of the 1940s best character actors.  And above all relish the dark humor that could only be pulled off in a more innocent time!

reviews.review_title: Fluffy screwball comedy of the highest order
reviews.content: An excellent example of Cary Grant in action.  He lives with two homicidal nut-case aunts (thus both the arsenic and the old lace), and fears their tendencies are heritable.  Thus he tries to avoid marriage with his sweetheart.  Madcap complications ensue involving his escaped prisoner brother.  Being a comedy, all ends well, with many laughs along the way.

One of the greatest movies ever made, has a shavian element to it (Not surprising considering that it was based on a play of that era). I believe it predated postmodernism but all the essential ingrediants are there. Making it a movie way ahead of its time. A must see.

reviews.review_title: Grant Really Knows How To Cary a Movie
reviews.content: Madcap, morbid hijinx that move along at a manic pace, lots and lots of laughs and just plain fun. It's a comedy/thriller and swings back and forth effortlessly. That cast alone would make it worthwhile!

This is truly one of Cary Grant's funniest movies. I never get tired of watching it. I believe they picked the right actors for the job. It combines comedy, horror, romance and insanity into one delightful movie. An excellent Halloween movie or anytime movie.

This is a very well-written script and probably would be better as a play. It lacks the smoothness needed for the big screen.  Strangely the worst part about the whole movie is Cary Grant's acting.  He's one of the top 10 actors of all time, but he was way over the top in this thing.  He appeared to think the movie was a big comedy, but the other actors treated it like a comedic drama, as they should have.  Grant was way off the mark on this one.There are some mild spoilers here, but I wouldn't think they'd damage your pleasure before you watched it.  Proceed at your own risk.The story is a little absurd, but that's where the comedy comes from.  A newlywed dramatic critic (Cary Grant) in the big city lives with his two aunts (Josephine Hull and Jean Adair) and an uncle (John Alexander).  Uncle Teddy is cookoo and thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt.  The aunts think he's the only one that's screwed up in the head, but, in fact, they are as well.  For they have been murdering lonely elderly gentlemen in their own home and burying them in the cellar.  When the nephew finds out, he goes a little weird himself in his attempt to figure out what to do about it.Everything gets worse when the long, lost, delinquent brother (Raymond Massey) returns home after a prison escape and is looking for a place to live and to bury his most recent victim.It's a plot that Hitchcock himself would have enjoyed, but there just wasn't clear direction of the acting and therefore no cohesiveness.  Frankly, I think the movie is tremendously overrated.  Not bad for a saturday night though.

reviews.review_title: S-O-O-O Bad, That It's ACTUALLY Good !!!
reviews.content: Having just seen Frank Capra's "Arsenic And Old Lace" (1944) for the 1st time, The ONLY Way that I can think of describing it is to say that it is S-O-O-O Bad, That It's ACTUALLY Good !!! It's Pure Camp for sure!!! A REAL Spoof, but I'm not quite sure WHAT it's even Spoofing !!!This is definitely "Cult Classic" material !!! The wide ranging cast of character actors did an excellent job !!! I was particularly impressed by the performance of Cary Grant, who I've only seen in suave, debonair leading man roles before. Grant really shows me the true breadth of his acting ability here, pulling off a slap stick comedic role quite convincingly & hilariously. His facial expressions are comedic gems.Although the fun of viewing this film is it's accelerating chaos, it required precision orchestration in many scenes, which were probably the result of many rehearsals & retakes. Capra did a remarkable job putting together this TOTAL Farce.VERY Entertaining !!! VERY Entertaining !!! joseph.kulik.919@gmail.com

reviews.review_title: One of the funniest movies I've seen.
reviews.content: Why did Cary Grant never win an Oscar?  Does this bug anyone else?  And especially for this movie!  This is an excellent movie!  I was laughing from the second it started up until the final credits.  Frank Capra has done it again with this picture.  Great casting all around, great script, and great direction.  Masterful movie.  Definitely a must-see.  Truly a classic comedy

I can honestly say that Arsenic and Old Lace is probably the funniest classic comedy that I have seen. The amount of ridiculous gags and absurd situations is enormous, making the film really enjoyable. It is sometimes so ludicrous that it's even hard to imagine how can anyone come up with a plot like this one.When a well-known drama critic Mortimer Brewster visits his two adorable aunts in order to tell them the fantastic new about his engagement to beautiful Elaine Harper, he finds out the horrible truth that spins the would-be quick meeting totally out of control. There is a dead man in the wooden box inside the house. But that is not all! There are eleven more buried under the residence. Then, there is also Teddy, who is a 100% sure that he is the late president Theodore Roosevelt. And if this was not enough, after some time we meet another member of this peculiar family - Jonathan (possessing a face that provokes a fantastic recurring gag concerning Boris Karloff), who shows up suddenly with his old friend Dr. Einstein.Even though that Cary Grant considered this to be one of his personal least favorite movies, his performance is so exaggerated that is almost excellent. For his character seems to be the only normal person in the entire household, trying to resolve all the farcical problems that occur throughout the whole film. One of them may be convincing the aunts that killing an innocent older man with an addition of arsenic to his wine is not right, because in their opinion they just shorten the miserable life a poor, lonely fellow. Another obstacle relates to the fact that his own brother, the gruesome Jonathan, wants to torture and kill him on the same exact night. Then, there is of course more action involving police officers and locked up corpses.If I'd have to pick one particular scene that I found the funniest (or the most absurd) I'd go with the conversation between aunts and Jonathan, who try to resolve a dispute about their little 'competition' - who killed more people! Because the sides are currently tied, one of them must be the winner, right? If you think that this is already too much you are very wrong, but I won't go into details, because I don't want to spoil the whole experience of watching this amazingly hilarious picture.All in all, I want to highly recommend this movie to EVERYONE. It is one of the funniest pictures ever made and it certainly didn't lose its charm after all those years. The jokes are intelligent and fresh, the cast is first-class and the remarkable screenplay will leave the most pleasant mark on your memory. Don't resist it, go and watch Arsenic and Old Lace today and remember: no refunds available when your stomach hurts like crazy after the amount of produced laughs!

reviews.review_title: One of the funniest films ever!
reviews.content: This is one of the best screwball comedies ever.Cary Grant's over the top performance just makes it more-so. One odd mistake (and this is not really a spoiler as this is how the film opens. We are told it's Halloween and then shown a baseball game playing in Brooklyn. In those days, the baseball season was well over by then.But that's is only a little baseball geek stuff. The cast is all superb. We even get James Gleason & Edward Everett Horton towards the end. Charles Lane plays a nosy reporter in a brief bit. And isn't Pricilla Lane a honey! The only regret is that they could not get Boris Karloff to play Jonathan but he was under contract to the Broadway version and it was still playing!

Classic screwball comedy topped by Cary Grant and superb supporting cast. The premise is so improbable you nearly groan but it's so funny and so enchanting because of Grant that you don't stray for a second not even for the bathroom. Indeed, this film is precisely the kind of story that set Grant apart from all other male stars. No male could achieve the kind of performance that Grant gives here and made so beloved as a screen star. The Philadelphia Story, Bringing Up Baby, and Topper are other examples of the kind of comedic tour de force for which Grant was so famous. Only when Grant teamed up with Hitchcock in Notorious, To Catch A Thief and North by Northwest did we see just how grand Grant could be in dramatic roles.

It has a first-rate cast, but Cary Grant's performance is subpar (for him, anyway -- he is said to have disliked the result and I can understand that feeling). He overacts tremendously, and I am convinced that it was Capra's fault, since Grant played the same sort of frustrated-to-distraction role perfectly in "Bringing Up Baby". The character of the fiancee is very lame, and apparently was rewritten for the screen. The rewrite for the screen apparently took much of the edge off the play. which may explain why the more ominous scenes with Massey seem so jarring when compared to the rest of the movie.Massey is fine as the evil "looks like Boris Karloff" brother, and Lorre is playing himself (which he does effortlessly). Anyway, there are moments, but the plot is poorly constructed and the movie is badly directed, so it's more interesting as an example of a sure hit that fails. (The play was a huge success on Broadway, and what a cast in the movie...)

reviews.review_title: DARK, COMEDIC NONSTOP EVENTS IN A HALLOWEEN EVENING
reviews.content:
Arsenic and Old Lace
Frank Capra's film Arsenic and Old Lace tells the story of Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant), a dramatic play critic who criticizes love, marriage, and honeymoons in his reviews preaching bachelorhood. Additionally, he published a book titled Marriage a Fraud and a Failure. Ironically, this dark comedy has Mortimer marry Elaine Harper (Pricilla Lane), the girl next door, on Halloween, and they return to the houses in Brooklyn where they grew up before leaving on their Niagara Falls honeymoon. Priscilla lives with her father, Reverend Harper (Grant Mitchell), at the church with a graveyard that separates Mortimer's Aunts Martha Brewster (Jean Adair), Abby Brewster (Josephine Hull), and his brother Teddy Roosevelt Brewster (John Alexander) house on the other side. His Aunts raised the brothers Teddy, Mortimer, and Johnathan Brewster (Raymond Massey), who returned home that Halloween evening to his Aunt's house with his sidekick plastic surgeon, Dr. Einstein (Peter Lorre).The theme of Arsenic and Old Lace (Capra, 1944) is murder, mayhem, and mental illness in the setting of Mortimer's Aunts home in Brooklyn, New York, on a Halloween evening. First, Aunt Martha and Aunt Abby are kind, pleasant older ladies who take in lonely borders, then offer them elderberry wine with strychnine, arsenic with a pinch of cyanide that kills them. Then Teddy, who has an identity disorder and thinks he is Teddy Roosevelt, is told to dig a canal for another yellow fever victim who needs to be buried by his Aunts. Finally, Johnathan has escaped prison for the criminally insane with Dr. Einstein, returns to the house with his own dead body, and plans to bury him in the canal after he finds out what his Autns have done in the cellar, and finally, his goal to have facial reconstruction by Einstein, so he does not look like Frankenstein.In this setting, many events within the Brewster family cause Mortimer to doubt his future mental health, especially what it may mean in his marriage to Elaine. Mortimer first arrives at Aunt Abby and Martha's house to tell them of the marriage and finds a body in the window seat, and he automatically thinks it is Teddy's. However, when speaking with Aunt Martha and Abby, he discovers they take in lonely male borders and offers them elderberry wine with poisons added. Mortimer then finds out that 12 men have been poisoned by his Aunts. Aunt Abby and Martha feel they are doing the right thing by poisoning them, and Teddy is clueless about the real cause of death because he thinks he is Teddy Roosevelt with the basement as Panama.Throughout the movie, Mortimer is troubleshooting and attempting to get Teddy committed to Happy Dale Sanatarium, stopping another potential border from drinking the elderberry wine, getting tied up by his brother Johnathon, and managing the police who stop in on their neighborhood beat. Likewise, Elaine is trying to figure out what is happening with Mortimer. These scenes constantly hop from one to the other throughout this evening in the Brewster house, making it mayhem for Mortimer and realizing that his whole family is mentally ill.Arsenic and Old Lace film is lighthearted with all characters except Johnathon and Dr. Einstein. Who could believe these sweet old ladies would ever cause harm to anyone? Alternatively, Teddy always charges up the stairs, blows his bugle, goes to Panama to dig canals, and appears harmlessly insane.Spoiler: In the end, Teddy, Aunt Martha, and Abby are all going to Happy Dale, Johnathan is arrested, and Dr. Einstein escapes. The main takeaway is that Mortimer is told by his Aunt that he was adopted and is not a blood relative, which makes him happy that he will not be insane and can go on with his life with Elaine.It is hard to find a film comparable to this black comedy. Other films of the era and beyond have murder and comedy, but none like Arsenic and Old Lace. It is a must-see for everyone.

reviews.review_title: I mildly cracked a smile. Once. Maybe.
reviews.content: I saw activity on the screen, secrets that people were trying to hide from one another, the alleged "map-cap-ness", Cary Grant learning of things at the same time as the audience and his expressions..I don't think I bought any of it because I just don't get why two old ladies killing people is funny. I'm watching two old sociopaths who belong in prison and that's supposed to be hilarious? The guy who thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt charging up the stairs, that got annoying REALLY fast. The other brother, who is also a sociopath, brought a dark element that didn't belong in a comedy. He wasn't funny, he was disturbing.I would say it was "watchable" but I would have preferred not to.

Grant hated his performance as Mortimer Brewster, but audiences loved it. Although he is known best as the supreme lead romantic actor (the man every man wish to be and the man every woman wanted to be with), his first love was doing comedy. Even in a Hitchcock thriller like "North by Northwest", Grant relished the chance to evoke laughter in his scene as a drunk.Based on the hit stage play, "Arsenic and Old Lace" is the quintessential dark comedy of its era. Josephine Hull and Jean Adair are priceless as the well-meaning sisters whose "ministry" is mercifully ending the lives of their lonely, elderly guests and burying them their basement. Raymond Massey is the menacing Johnathan Brewster. Pricilla Lane is winningly cute as Mortimer's confused bride-to-be. Peter Lorre is the shifty but sympathetically conflicted Dr. Einstein. And if you haven't seen John Alexander as the delusional Teddy Brewster, you're in for an unforgettable treat!Enjoy the Brewster sisters' hospitality, but I don't advise drinking the wine!!!

Frank Capra's Arsenic and Old Lace is a marvelous reproduction of Joseph Kesserling's renowned Broadway hit. Cleverly directed, brilliantly acted and scripted, it is a prime example of black comedy at its best.The actors (particularly Massey and Lorre as two of the era's most original and disturbing villains) are perfectly cast in rolls that they truly bring to life. There are many memorable scenes and lines ("No! Not the Melbourne Method!") and each player gets a turn in the spotlight. Indeed, while watching, I was under the impression that everyone must have had a wonderful time making this picture. This is truly a peculiar film in that it excellently balances the mood between light-hearted comic adventure and borderline horror. In fact, one may have a hard time recognizing this as a work from Capra, owing to the amount of bizarre shenanigans and twists that beset the plot.Packed with witty blocks of conversation, extraordinary personalities, and an interesting setting, Arsenic and Old Lace is highly recommended viewing for all. If you have not yet had a chance to see this timeless classic, please consider it on your next trip to the video rental and you won't regret it!

This is a very funny movie showing the silly side of Cary Grant. The movie was based on a very successful Broadway play. Warner Bros. bought the movie rights just after the play opened with the agreement not to release the movie until after the play closed its run on Broadway. Most successful plays of the time lasted no more than a few months or maybe even a year. Warner went ahead and made the movie thinking that by the time it was finished shooting the movie the play would have finished it's run also. Unfortunately for Warner the very funny play was so successful during that time of national emotional stress that it ran for over three years. The movie had to sit on the shelf for three years before it could be released.

reviews.review_title: If you don't think this is funny you're taking it too seriously
reviews.content: This film has what is known as "slapstick"quality-quick dialogue, nonsensical plot, generally silly. This is a classic example. Cary Grant was famous for these films with their witty/cutting banter. Generally these movies are adaptations of stage plays which is why they may seem a little "stagey". This style of film is just that-a style like film noir which can seem stilted or overdone but remember- movies with sound hadn't been around long so entertainment to most peoplewas vaudeville and/or stage plays. Perhaps looking at these films in this light will help you to understand the pacing and the historical placement of thesefilms in time. Most of the comedies of the 40's have this identical theme- Philadelphia Story, Bringing Up Baby, His Gal Friday, etc.

reviews.review_title: "Insanity runs in my family...it practically gallops."
reviews.content: I go back and forth between this and It Happened One Night, but Arsenic and Old Lace may just be Capra's greatest film. It's a black comedy but it never loses the Capraesque sentimentality. Two sweet old ladies are murdering people and yet the tone of the film is about as affectionately idealistic as Capra's It's A Wonderful Life. There's something truly charming about that.Enough can't be said about the casting. Raymond Massey and Peter Lorre play almost caricatures of their characters, and yet they do it so well you almost don't even notice, until of course the story takes a moment to literally point these things out. Cary Grant, who famously said that he didn't look back fondly on this role for fear that he overacted, is brilliant. Maybe there's truth to his words, maybe there is some overacting here, but it feels so necessary for the character that it's impossible to imagine Mortimer any other way.And through the sentimental tone there is some truly great humor at play here. Grant and Massey both rushing to the window seat followed by Grant's realization to what has happened will never not get a laugh from me, and the scene where the police in the background read out a description of Peter Lorre's character as he is standing in the foreground as he has to agonizingly listen is comedic gold.There's something so incredibly beautiful about this movie that I have tried to put into words countless times throughout the years and I somehow always come up short. All I can say is I can and in all likelihood will watch it at least a hundred more times before I die and even then I shall never tire of it.

reviews.review_title: A well made film that isn't a comedy due to using mental illness for the jokes
reviews.content: I'm baffled by the reviews of this movie. It is well made, but that doesn't excuse portraying mental illnesses for laughs. It doesn't hold up in this way for a modern viewer. It's like watching racist depictions now. In this way I can't rate this movie any higher than 6. A shame really because the movie is expertly directed by Capra.

I am sentimentally attached to this play since I did the Einstein part in two different little theater productions - two years apart. Yep, Lorre is my hero, and I doubt anyone else could have played the part as well as he did on Broadway and in this hilarious movie.Some critics say that this is home turf for Capra. Actually, it is not. Zaniness is not his stock in trade but, whatever he helms has the golden touch.The dark humor plot may be difficult for some - murder not often going for laughs, but it worked beautifully this time. I've sat through this movie about a dozen times, I know most of the dialogue, and I still laugh at everything that happens.Grant was not thrilled with his role, feeling it was too far over the top, but Grant did not give Grant enough credit. Sure, he stretches, and the more he does so, the funnier the scenes.Hope and Benny were the first choices. Benny with his familiar put-upon expressions would have done well. It's just that the versatile Grant is perfection-plus in one of his own least favorite roles. He is outnumbered by his millions of fans. The public lapped it up.The entire cast made it work, especially, of course, Abe Lincoln. Boy, talk about versatile.The old ladies, Jack Carson whose expressions seldom change from movie to movie. Horton and horn-tooting Teddy all make it work.If you reside next to Elisha Cook Jr., and you've never seen the ill effect of arsenic and elderberry, make it a point to check out "Arsenic and Old Lace." The lace may be old, but it holds up beautifully.

Over a drinking conversation, a friend asked me what was the darkest film ever made. Instinctively, I said Arsenic and Old Lace - a film I hadn't seen in over twenty years. My friend had never seen the film, and asked general questions about it. When I told him that it was a Frank Capra film he seemed incredulous. I guess he couldn't peg the director of Mr. Smith Goes To Washington with making a dark film.To tell the truth, neither could I - not on recall alone. That weekend, I plopped a borrowed copy into my DVD player, and watched the film again. After the first reel, which now seemed plodding, it all rushed back to me why this film was dark: It seemed that Mr. Capra had lost his naïveté, and filmed why he lost it.Mortimer Brewster (Cary Grant) is a famed drama critic for a New York paper. But mostly, he is known for his stance against marriage and the many books he has written mocking the institution. One Halloween, in which the Brooklyn Dodgers get into a real row of a fight, Mortimer and the love of his life - the girl next door, Elaine Harper (Priscilla Lane) - get married. Mortimer, fearing the deluge of negative comments of the famed bachelor tying the knot, brings Elaine by their folks' houses to announce their marriage before they sail away for a two-month voyage. It is here where Mortimer's life falls off the cliff. When he tells the kindly old Aunts that raised him, Abby (Josephine Hull) and Martha (Jean Adair) Brewster, the news, he discovers that the nicest people in Brooklyn have been putting arsenic in their homemade elderberry wine, and knocking off lonely old gentlemen. The news gets worse. It seems that Mortimer has repressed memories of the violence that was done to him by his brother, Jonathan Brewster (Raymond Massey), when he was a child. Plus, there is the delusional uncle who thinks he is Teddy Roosevelt. In all, after a half-hour, Mortimer now fears for Elaine's safety, for he believes he is as loony as the rest of the Brewsters.By the way, this is a comedy. It was adapted from a hit Broadway play starring Mr. Frankenstein himself, Boris Karloff. He actually was supposed to be in the movie also, but couldn't leave the play. Frank Capra directed Arsenic and Old Lace in the genre of the screwball comedies of the thirties. He shot it five months after the play premiered. He had previous success in the field of screwball comedies with It Happened One Night. Old Lace also could be considered a film noir piece with the abundant nighttime location shoots, and very dark interiors. The Brewster house provided for very ominous, long shadows. But if this was a noir film - I say it is - then it would be Capra's first. And the question would be "Why"?It was an obvious choice to cast Cary Grant, who had drawn crowds to several screwball comedies since his first screen role in She Done Him Wrong. In every one of these genre roles, he played the straight, sane one - the one who gets more insane as the plot progresses. (Of particular note, in later years, Grant held a very low opinion of both She Done Him Wrong and Arsenic and Old Lace. He found She Done Him Wrong and Mae West to be too sexual. And he found Arsenic and Old Lace to be too dark and cynical.) At the time of the play's release, America was in the beginnings of WWII. And maybe dark themes were all that could be tolerated by an entertainment seeking public. It and Sweeny Todd are definitely the darkest of the light theatrical subjects. And strangely enough both plays were released around American wars. Maybe funny comedies had to show a dark sense of humor. Or light musicals for that matter had to explore horror. Unlike Sweeny Todd the movie, Arsenic and Old Lace was a hit - mainly because it was shot within months after it opened, and released soon after it closed. By that time Europe was close to D-Day.

reviews.review_title: Good suspense movie directed by Frank Capra.
reviews.content: This is one of many Frank Capra movies that I like. It begins simple enough: A baseball game in Brooklyn. Then, Mortimer and Elaine getting married. Then the graveyard: "From here in, you're on you're own." We find out that Mortimer is a bachelor-happy author, and had written a book about it, much to the dismay of the Reverend in the town, who also happened to be Elaine's father.Meanwhile, Morimer's brother Teddy, who thinks that he's Teddy Roosevelt and acts like him, (and looks like him too) calls the house THe White House, and keeps blowing a bugle, much to the dismay of the neighbors.Mortimer find out that his two aunts, adored by all in the city, are killing off "lonely old men" and burying them in the cellar. Then Jonathan, Mortimer's brother, shows up. He looks like Boris Karloff, the actor who played Frankenstein's monster. Jon has a sidekick German-accented "Doctor Einstien" who had performed the surgery, but had been drunk while doing it. Jon always gets upset at the mention of his look alikeness to the actor, and had killed people for saying it.Eventually, everything is set right, though Einstein escapes, Jonathan doesn't. The police get him, and Teddy is sent to Happy Dale, a place for . . . people like Teddy.My Score: 7/10.

reviews.review_title: One of the First Black Comedies
reviews.content: Arsenic and Old Lace starring Cary Grant, Josephine Hull, Jean Adair, Raymond Massey, Peter Lorre and Jack Carson (amazing job) is a very funny black comedy. In fact, it is one of Hollywood's original, perhaps finest.Cary Grant plays a writer called Mortimer Bruster who just got married (despite the fact he 'poo-pooed' marriage in his books) and goes back to his Aunt's place to tell them, only to find they are serial killers and bury the bodies in the cellar! They are hilariously good natured aunts though, as they insist they are doing it for the good of the men as they are lonely. Before Mortimer can gather his thoughts, his bizarre Frankenstein-looking brother Johnny comes back - for good. So much to handle on your wedding night! Although I found it over-acted at times with lots of screaming, shouting and yelling, I wouldn't want it any other way. This is what black comedy is about. Timeless classic.

reviews.review_title: Why does everyone love it so?
reviews.content: I hated this movie.  It's SICK, SICK I tell you!  Little old ladies murdering people, this is what everyone thinks is oh-so-hilarious? Ugghhh.....  I shudder for humanity.

reviews.review_title: Stay out of the Panama Canal!
reviews.content: A well filmed, well acted movie. I have seen it quite a few times now, and it always goes by fast, which tends to = GOOD FLICK.I sometimes find Cary Grant's comedic acting a bit over the top, but seeing as his character has begun to worry that he has inherited his family's "mental health issues", I can overlook that.Peter Lorre actually seems to be acting rather natural, even though he is playing a rather corrupt doctor. Raymond Massey is perfect as the long lost (and violent) brother. Basically, every role was well cast, and I'd suggest the film to anyone who wants a chuckle.... just stay out of the Panama Canal...

reviews.review_title: Mimics of Cary Grant is just a reason to watch it
reviews.content: One of the most indispensable face of Hitchcock films is of course Cary Grant and lots of Hitchcock movies are placed in my cinema archive. I haven't seen Grant in such a funny role neither in Hitchcock films nor other films. Comedy can be described as macabre or absurd. This is a film that manages to combine the two with uncanny perfection. From two sweet old aunties that turn out to be kindly serial killers, to an uncle that thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt and yells "CHAAAAARRRRGE!!!!!" as he runs up the homestead's stair case because, to him, it is San Juan Hill, to a brother that's a certifiable psychopath and has as his unhappiest life moment the fact that his aunties are 1 ahead of him in the murder department, Arsenic and Old Lace never seems to run out of ways to make things more and more ridiculous.Yet with all the implausibility of the plot line, it never fails to hold one's attention. I found the most driving force in the film was simply that I had to know how the story could possibly untangle enough to deliver an ending that didn't feel forced. It managed it quite nicely.Cary Grant is terrific. Everyone in the film is. Peter Lorre is magnificent in what I think is an unusual comedic role as the violently homicidal brother's flunky.The mood of this gem of a film simply can't be described sufficiently in words. It must be experienced. So go watch it. NOW! Really. You won't regret it.

It all flows along like a great piece of work and there's not one let down throughout. I'm not sure why he hates this movie, it's not as if he'd been doing a bunch of different films the same way, this is a once in a career looking role, and he fits it to a tee, alongside his strangely irregular cast-mates. Fun for the complete two hours.

reviews.review_title: One Of The Best Comedies Ever & A Hugely Talented Cast
reviews.content: I don't know why some others don't "get it" when they see this film. This is one of the most hilarious comic inventions ever - with a cast that's so full of great stars (and top-notch seasoned character actors) at their very best that it shines like a universe of bright lights. (And it's one of Frank Capra's very best - and most unusual films, for a man who normally represented "Americana" and charm. This falls outside his norm. It's just zany!)Plus - unlike other comedies - it builds and builds with tension until the very end.And like all great movies, it's full of memorable scenes and lines you'll be quoting forever (including Garry Owen's throwaway line (as the incredulous cab driver), "I'm a teapot!" - which you'll understand when you hear it).Even IF Cary Grant weren't in this film delivering one of his very very best comic performances ever, there are so many performances and reasons to see this film it's impossible to list them all here. Josephine Hull and Jean Adair practically steal this movie, for example - and that's saying a lot in a movie chock full of amazingly awesome performances, such as: Fine actor Raymond Massey's scary yet hilarious performance as a Frankenstein-like Jonathan Brewster (and what a stretch for him!) Peter Lorre's off-the-charts delightfully schizophrenic performance as the alcoholic and sadistic yet strangely caring at times Dr. Einstein Jack Carson's hilarious performance as a dumb cop with a dream of becoming a playwright John Alexander's performance as a mad but lovable relative of Cary's who thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt Edward Everett Horton's brilliant performance as a "rest home" director ...And it goes on and on from there.While this also functions as a "romantic" comedy - since Priscilla Lane is wooing Cary throughout - this is the not your traditional romantic comedy and I suggest that that ruse was grafted on to lighten the premise. It's necessary to the film but not what it's "all about."Hopefully you'll give this movie a chance and "get it" - because this is one of the wildest and most incredible comic rides you'll ever take.

reviews.review_title: One of the four funniest movies ever made.
reviews.content: Cary Grant said, more than once, that the only film he wished he hadn't made was Arsenic and Old Lace. Cary was one of the most brilliant actors ever to grace the screen, and his own self-deprecation of this movie proves the rule that the best actors make the worst critics. This is far and away the best movie the old boy ever made and the best performance he ever turned in  and, given The Philadelphia Story, Mr Blandings Builds His Dream House, Charade and many others, that's saying something.If you believe that performance art is actually art, that Martin Scorcese directs comedy well, or that Quentin Tarntino is an actual person instead of a character created by Andy Kaufman  don't waste time watching this movie. You have neither the wit nor the sophistication to appreciate it.Following the best formula for comedy, Frank Capra starts with two great leads, creates circumstances which make them both lunatics, and then surrounds them with brilliant comedic actors playing characters who are raving lunatics on their best days. This formula is why Arsenic and Old Lace, Young Frankenstein, What's Up Doc and Love and Death are brilliant, while Fletch is merely funny (Dick Libertini, Ken Mars, George Wendt et al playing straight men for anyone is inherently wrong).This is the archetypical door-slamming comedy  with a few dozen murders and a family that would make Hannibal Lector faint dead away thrown in for laughs. Cary, as the only normal member of the family, turns in a performance that is suave, yet slapstick to a degree that would do Harpo Marx or Larry Fine proud. The female lead (who isn't seen all that much) is the equally brilliant Priscilla Lane, who made far too few movies. Add in Raymond Massey, Peter Lorre, Jack Carson, James Gleason, Edward Everett Horton and lots of other great comedians and you get funny in spades.Mortimer Brewster (Grant), theater critic and author of books against marriage, has just married the minister's daughter (Lane) who lives next door to the two maiden Aunts in Brooklyn who raised him. They stop to tell them on their way to Niagara Falls. You get to see Mortimer's brother Teddy, who thinks he's Theodore Roosevelt, and, in incidental conversation, learn of the psychotic third brother, Jonathan, who's long since departed. But, as least Mort knows good old Aunts Abby and Martha are sane ... until he finds the china closet full of men's hats and learns about the little "charity" service they've been performing. Of course, while he's trying to sort out the chaos he thought was order, Jonathan returns with two friends, one living.While best viewed just before Halloween, this movie is an absolute treat any time. The dialogue is great, the slapstick is splendid, and there are more and better double-takes than any other film. Watch Cary use every muscle in his face as he intones "Now, Aunt Abby, when you say 'others' do you mean others  as in more than one others?!?" If Raymond Massey's Jonathan doesn't frighten you to your toes, and if Cary doing a prancing pantomime while singing "there is a happy dale far, far away" doesn't put you on the floor  call the ME's, you're as good as dead.

Based on the smash hit play by Joseph Kesselring and directed by Frank Capra, Arsenic and old lace is charmingly cozy Halloween comedy for every season. AAOL is based off the play by the same name. It centers around the comic life of two, young newly-weds who are getting ready to go on their honeymoon! Soon to leave for his honeymoon, he is aghast to learn that there is a corpse of a dead man in the dais of their sun-window in the front parlor. Assuming that his demented (but sweet) relative Ted did the dastardly deed himself (after all, Ted thinks he's Teddy Roosevelt!), Grant learns that his aunties did this murder, and have been doing it for many years. All is Okay though, because the sweet ladies are killing these aged old men off for charity, so that they don't live too long in aged agony! Add to the farce, there are eleven more bodies buried in the basement, and Ted buries them thinking they are simply victims of Yellow Fever from digging the Panama Canal.

Yesterday I received my new DVD in the mail from the Warner Archive of Frank Capra's classic screwball horror comedy "ARSENIC AND OLD LACE" (WB, 1944) and watched it last night. I hadn't seen it in many years, and it was terrific to watch this comedy gem again! One of the most entertaining movies made in the 1940s. Cary Grant was incredible as a physical comedian, as Mortimer Brewster, and I was comparing his performance to say, Jerry Lewis, and it is really way over the top! I consider this film to be Cary Grant's greatest comedy performance! Priscilla Lane as his fiancée/wife was such a beautiful, sweet blonde, sweet as honey, the two naughty aunts with their bad habits of poisoning lonely old men with their arsenic-laced elderberry wine were superb; John Alexander as the wacko-nutcase Brewster brother who thinks he is Teddy Roosevelt was also a standout: "Charge!" as he runs up the staircase, as he was as the fallen angel Doremus in Jack Benny's HORN BLOWS AT MIDNIGHT (1945), and Raymond Massey in full horror makeup (including some very realistic-looking stitched scars on his face) as a diabolically evil Karloff-knockoff horror character, Jonathan Brewster, is fantastic! Of course, those of us who have done our homework on this picture know that Karloff played this very role in the Broadway play! And Peter Lorre, as his lesser, but just as diabolical sidekick (whose fluid acting makes him seem to be a cartoon character) Dr. Einstein, is terrific! Plus Jack Carson as the knucklehead cop on the beat O'Hara, with the added understated comedy performances of Edward Everett Horton as Mr. Witherspoon, the happy-go-lucky director of Happydale Sanitarium, matchstick-slim James Gleason as the police inspector (who goes from being a police lieutenant to a captain in the dialogue), a brief appearance of crusty old Charles Lane, makes this movie a wonderful Halloween masterpiece, originally filmed in late 1941, and released about a month before Halloween 1944. Capra at his very best! Highly Recommended for the Dead Comedians Society!

Review: Arsenic and Old Lace.As one of the few films I hadn't seen on the list, I was quite looking forward to this one. I was told to expect a charming black comedy, I wasn't disappointed.The premise of the film, two old spinster sisters living together and killing lonely old men, doesn't seem overly appealing. It sounds like an attempt to imitate the quirky British comedies of the same era. However this is something quite different. It is mainly a bit of silly fun. It doesn't take itself seriously at all, and you can tell that most of the actors involved thought that the picture would be something they could have a laugh with.The energy of the piece is what brings it alive. As I have mentioned, the actors really bring it to life. Carey Grant, for once, is very good. However the actor who play's Teddy deserves a special mention. For me, he makes the film, without his influence I feel it would be a slightly above average comedy. But the sheer amount of one liners, quips, and great acting brings him to the forefront of the film.I enjoyed this film, but nowhere near as much as Kind Hearts, which is a shinning example of how a dark comedy should be done. Good film, but perhaps overly reliant on Teddy for gags.8/10

reviews.review_title: A Movie in the Time of the Hayes Codes
reviews.content: "Arsenic and Old Lace" tells the story of two older women who kill a man and their antics following the murder as well the Teddy, who think he is Theodore Roosevelt. This movie is filled with hilarity that makes absolutely no sense, which is common in movies made the era of the Hayes Codes. Movies like "My Man Godfrey," and "Palm Beach Story" follow almost impossible story line filled ridiculousness. The reason for all the absurdness is the Hayes Codes. The Hayes Codes were a series of rules that outlined what a movie could and could not have within it's contents. For example, man and wife could not share a bed, the could not be any violence, unless to bring the bad guy to justice, and the bad guys could not win in the end. With all these rules, there was nothing else to make movie-wise but absurd, and nonsensical movies.
